@cafreiman It seems more broadly true that groups that really emphasize being warm and fluffy and egalitarian internally often have a dark side of being unwelcoming to outsiders.

I wonder what the exceptions are and what we can learn from them.

Another pattern I despise is insisting on a really important difference in meaning to words that sound like synonyms.

"complex vs complicated"
"money vs currency"
"decentralized vs distributed"

No. Stop. Let them be synonyms, use more specific words that clarify the difference.

Often when a word has a confusing meaning, the most viable path is to just stop using it. "Fortnightly" is too obscure; I'd probably just say "twice per month" and "every 2 months" (eg. "your salary is $2500 twice per month") directly.

Recommend this.

Giving money directly to the poorest people in the world is a simple effective way of greatly improving people's lives that we can all get behind.
Continue to appreciate your role in making these writings accessible to more people!

@StonkyGems @MayorOfMatic @OpenAIERC Most farmers these days are large corporations (eg. Bill Gates owns a lot). The idea that the average farmer is a friendly mom and pop is an intentional psyop.

But a per-person exemption to the land value tax targeted to middle class levels could easily be introduced if needed.

@alfegaly Pragmatic libertarians should accept that governments having budgets is good, because they can spend it on welfare programs which substitute economically ugly and intrusive stuff like rent control, rationing, strict labor regulation, etc

Land value tax helps with this.

@alfegaly Land value tax is one of the forms of taxation that requires the *least* authoritarian/intrusive compliance infrastructure.

It avoids taxing transactions entirely, and it's only looking at land, not improvements, so you don't even need to peek into each person's property.

@MayorOfMatic It is, but:

1. The rates are not high enough
2. Assessed values are often waaay lower than market values (prop 13 in California defnitely makes this so)
3. Land tax taxes only land, not value of improvements (incl buildings), which is nicer in a whole bunch of ways

A particular tragedy that is totally not the @OpenAI @StableDiffusion and co builders' fault, is that people's expectations (including my own) get set by the dazzling stuff that goes viral, and its average case performance inevitably can't match that.

My one-sentence summary of the AI right now is that it does amazing stuff but it has a high error rate.

This is why it both impresses and frustrates: the times it does really well go viral on twitter, the times it makes a mistake frustrate people using it as a work aid.

@el33th4xor Token voting governance is a superlinear mechanic: if you're a small holder your chance to influence the outcome is tiny and your ability to benefit from any influence is tiny, so your power is tiny^2, whereas large holders can force decisions and benefit massively from them

@el33th4xor "Holding this token enables you to extract" is too simplistic, because the whole point is the key difference between linear extraction (ok in some cases) and superlinear extraction (leads to centralization dynamics)
@el33th4xor In many protocols, token holders can literally vote on protocol changes.
@el33th4xor That's not a "governance" right. Stakers and MEV extractors don't get special seats at all core devs calls.

* past state X is valid
* no txs from account A after X, therefore 
* you can still withdraw coins you had in state X

Also, I would love to see rules written in such a way that requirements can be satisfied by zero knowledge proofs as much as possible. ZKPs offer lots of new opportunities to satisfy reg policy goals and preserve privacy at the same time, and we should take advantage of this!

Regs on defi frontends that *could* be more helpful may include:

(i) limits on leverage
(ii) requiring transparency about what audits, FV or other security checks were done on contract code
(iii) usage gated by knowledge-based tests instead of plutocratic net-worth minimum rules

Basically, there's two main classes of regulatory policy goals: (i) consumer protection, (ii) making it harder for baddies to move large amounts of money around. The issues around (ii) are concentrated not in defi, but in large-scale crypto payments in general.

The "KYC on defi frontends" idea does not seem very pointful to me: it would annoy users but do nothing against hackers. Hackers write custom code to interact with contracts already. Exchanges are clearly a much more sensible place to do the KYC, and that's happening already.

Basically, especially at this time, regulation that leaves the crypto space free to act internally but makes it harder for crypto projects to reach the mainstream is much less bad than regulation that intrudes on how crypto works internally.

Another maybe-controversial take of mine is that I don't think we should be enthusiastically pursuing large institutional capital at full speed. I'm actually kinda happy a lot of the ETFs are getting delayed. The ecosystem needs time to mature before we get even more attention.

The good news is that we're narrowing down toward an actual path for account abstraction, something we've always wanted but have not managed to actually have!

These can't be done with an ERC. They require an actual consensus-changing EIP.

* EIP-3074 does the first
* EIP-5003 does the second
* No EIPs yet for the third, but see an introduction to the problem and a solution path here: https://t.co/BuNaxM7FpM

Now, problems that are NOT solved by ERC-4337!

* Letting existing EOAs send ops that get paid for by third parties
* Upgrading existing EOAs to contracts
* Integration with transaction inclusion lists (an anti-censorship feature in PBS)

The signature aggregation feature allows builders and batch submitters to also aggregate signatures (eg. BLS, later with SNARKs), greatly reducing the data that goes on chain. This is a critical cost-saving feature for rollups, where data costs dominate.

https://t.co/0b7wgoAJmq

But if you use this feature, then you are relying on some external mechanism to pay for the op, and you should better be sure that it won't disappear on you!

(If it does, you would have to pay ETH and push the op through yourself)
The "paymaster" feature allows paymaster contracts, which let you separate "who pays for the op" and "who sends the op".

All this ensures that if an op gets broadcasted through the mempool, then it is guaranteed that that op can get included on-chain and will pay fees - unless another op from that same account gets in first. Like Ethereum txs today.

All this prevents DoS attacks on the mempool.

ERC-4337, and its predecessor EIP-2938, do this by enshrining a split between "validation" and "execution".

The validation step is bounded in how much gas it can consume, and cannot use "forbidden opcodes" that access state outside the account. If an op does this, it is rejected

Doing this securely requires a mempool node to be able to determine whether or not a given op is guaranteed to pay fees before rebroadcasting it.

This is quite hard to do, because it requires checking that the op does not depend on state that might change in the next block.

This is the gold standard that the existing public mempool provides. And we absolutely need to provide the same guarantees for smart contract wallets, or else we risk worsening centralization and censorship.

You should be able to send an op into a public mempool, and if it pays enough fees, reliably expect it to get included. This should NOT depend on ANY:

* Centralized actors
* Reputation systems for op senders
* ETH held in a separate EOA
* External services for account creation

The big really valuable and necessary thing that ERC-4337 provides for account abstraction is a *decentralized fee market* for user operations going into smart contract wallets.

I try to explain the additive vs multiplicative notation issue for elliptic curves, and get a little bit into the question of what to do with the GT group.
It's also the anniversary of the 2016 Shanghai DoS attacks.
@davidonchain H is already pronounced "aych"; if you want to go lobby to rename it "huh" (and W to "we" or "wuh") I'll support you, but I'm trying to start with the low hanging fruit here first.

@Galois_Capital @TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson That doesn't work because ‚ö¨ is commutative and exponentiation is not.

I recommend you go take first year linear algebra or some coursera equivalent before you argue big boy topics with us any more.
@0xninicha @TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson Multiplication is a function.

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson But even if you're not willing to use "+" for GT multiplication, you can still use additive notation for elliptic curve crypto (and I do). But then, you want to use e(A, B) instead of A * B for pairings to avoid confusing people.
@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson And so this is the debate. Do we make the black-box view cleaner, or do we make it more accurately describe what's going on "under the hood"?

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson This makes a lot of pedantically inclined people's brains explode. Noooo, you can't just pretend that it's addition, it literally is multiplication! And yet if you pretend it's addition, it just makes describing cryptographic protocols soooo much easier.

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson But, and here's the fun part, from a mathematical perspective, the ‚ö¨ operation between GT elements *literally is multiplication*. And so if we want the math to look clean when treating A, B and X as a black box, we have to pretend that multiplication in GT is addition.

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson And the fun question. What do we call the ‚ö¨ operation above? From a "black box" perspective, it seems correct to just call it addition. After all, if you plug in numbers instead of curve points to the equation, and `A * B = X`, then `(3A) * B = A * (3B) = X + X + X` is correct.

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson Now, we get to pairings. Described in additive notation, pairings let you "multiply" two elliptic curve points *by each other* (the result is not a curve point, but a different thing called a "GT element")

A * B = X
(3A) * B = A * (3B) = X‚ö¨X‚ö¨X
(A + C) * B = A * B ‚ö¨ C * B

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson But people "born and raised" in elliptic curve land are more likely to prefer additive notation, because it's more convenient.

Eg. in Schnorr signatures:

Sign: s = r - x * e
Verify: R = G * s + X * e

In additive notation, it's easier to see the "symmetry" between the two eqs.

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson "Traditional cryptographers" often tend to prefer multiplicative notation, in part because in forms of cryptography that were popular before elliptic curves, the equivalent to ‚ö¨ literally was multiplication. RSA, for example, uses multiplication and exponentiation.

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson "Additive notation" means using the "‚ö¨ = addition, repeated ‚ö¨ = multiplication" metaphor for elliptic curve points.

"Multiplicative notation" means using the "‚ö¨ = multiplication, repeated ‚ö¨ = exponentiation" metaphor.

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson For example, the standard way to convert a private key `k` into the corresponding public key `K` is to agree on a standardized generator point `G`, and apply the operation to it `k` times:

K = G‚ö¨G‚ö¨G ... G  [with `k` G's]

@TrustlessState @ArthurB @danrobinson There is an operation A‚ö¨B -> C on elliptic curve points, and we often do it to the same point many times: A‚ö¨A‚ö¨A ... ‚ö¨A -> D

There are 2 ways to talk about this:

1. ‚ö¨ = "addition", repeating it = "multiplication"
2. ‚ö¨ = "multiplication", repeating it = "exponentiation"
@danrobinson The chad take is to use additive notation even for the GT group.

Quantum computers break:

* RSA and anything based on factoring
* Elliptic curves
* Unknown order groups

Quantum computers don't break:

* Hashes
* Lattices

https://t.co/i6lCDufs9v

Many of you got this one very wrong btw. Quantum computers with Shor's algorithm break elliptic curves completely. Hashes (like SHA256) survive quantum computers just fine, though security degrades somewhat and longer hash lengths become recommended. https://t.co/z6wnG2Id1F

Computer programs are built on theory, neural nets are built on intuition and empiricism.

Different way of thinking. And different conclusions come out of that way of thinking.

Computer programs are highly structured, they are legible, and they are either perfect or have bugs that break things horribly until fixed.

Neural nets are highly illegible, they make mistakes, but somehow even mistaken answers are... kinda reasonable? https://t.co/BCVRR2oBkl

When people say things like "human beings are not algorithms", sometimes they're not literally asserting a spirit world not describable with math and physics, rather they're saying: we're different from *computer programs written by humans*. We're more similar to neural nets.

Neural networks as philosophy:

Late 20th century philosophical thought was heavily influenced by intuitions from study of computers and algorithms: *we too* are algorithms, what could those insights say about us?

I wonder if the 21st century will do the same with neural nets.

@PeterMcCormack Because it's not a circular argument, it's a spiral argument. People with coins at time T secure the transactions at time T+1.

Spiral arguments and circular arguments sometimes look similar to untrained observers, but they are fundamentally different.

@nicksdjohnson @ArthurB Not sure what you mean. I'm not suggesting a years-long transfer procedure. I'm suggesting a cap on how quickly the fee can rise, so you can put down a fixed amount and guarantee ownership for N years.
@nicksdjohnson @ArthurB So I think there's a strong case for taking a more pure-private-property approach for long domains and some harberger thing for short ones!
@nicksdjohnson @ArthurB Short domains are the ones that are most scarce, and so the ones where "unfairness to people in 2050" from making them claimable-in-perpetuity today is the greatest.

@nicksdjohnson @ArthurB I see the point, but I think the number of years of stability needed to get most of the gains of stability is much less than infinity.

@nicksdjohnson @ArthurB https://t.co/ePgUGcgL8q

@nicksdjohnson @ArthurB I just think that giving people in 2020 any guarantees of continued ownership in 2050 regardless of future market conditions is fundamentally incompatible with any reasonable notion of fairness to people living in 2050.

@nicksdjohnson @ArthurB You can modify it so that you can guarantee ownership for N years (eg. by capping the growth rate of the fee).

I don't think being able to guarantee ownership for an arbitrary duration with a finite (or linear) amount of money is a desirable property for a domain system to have.

Worst-case nuclear war might kill 1-2 billion, full-on extinction will kill 8 billion, but adding in longtermist arguments the latter number grows to 999999...999 billion. So taking longtermist issues into account meaningfully changes relative priorities.

@OptiChads @thejonmccoy cos when you multiply by a tan you're committing a sin
@thejonmccoy Please don't use tan to generate your wallet seeds.

The spikes emerge from good approximations to the circle ratio:

11/7 ~= tau/4 (or pi/2)
11 ~= 7/4 * tau (one full rotation plus 270.25')

So tan(11) is high: -225.95

The spikes near 355 and 710 are "echoes" of 11/7 created because 355/113 is an *amazing* approximation of tau/2

What's even more interesting is that tan(int) is *not* a random number generator. There's fascinating patterns in the data.

One way to look at it is: if tan(x) is very high, x is very close to a 90' or 270' angle. So if tan(x) and tan(y) are high, tan(x + 2y) is also high. https://t.co/W2QlBsUDBM
And if you use tan^2 you get into total crazy land. https://t.co/g1Z9gIlRGL

I continue to find probability distributions with infinite means fascinating. Particularly how their averages *don't converge* as you sample more values.

You can even replicate the behavior deterministically with "tan at integers" as a pseudo-RNG. https://t.co/KmfUXpqKLx

@kelvinfichter Right but while you're not yet ready to fully trust ZKPs, you want to guard against both ZKPs liveness failures and ZKP safety failures (invalid state transitions having valid-looking proofs). Hence the ability to start an optimistic challenge game while waiting for the ZKP.
Reducing fraud proof time to 24h is safe because an attack would require both blocking challenges for 24h *and* breaking one of the three resolution mechanisms.

Hybrid idea: optimistic + ZK, governance only adjudicates bugs between the two

1. Publish block
2. Wait 24h for fraud challenges.
3a. If no challenge, publish ZK SNARK, finalize.
3b. If there is a challenge, decide based on 2-of-3 of (challenge game, ZK SNARK, governance)

@BSmokes_ @TimBeiko @ercwl @allenf32 @udiWertheimer @adam3us Poisson process means there is a tiny chance of something happening every millisecond. Blocks in PoW are like this.

In PoS, a block appears once every 12s, it's a scheduled interval.
@TimBeiko @ercwl @allenf32 @udiWertheimer @adam3us These gains are limited in practice because state is the main bottleneck and not execution, but they're there.

@TimBeiko @ercwl @allenf32 @udiWertheimer @adam3us Also, "PoS doesn't help scaling" is overstated. It does somewhat:

* No Poisson process -> no linear uncle rates ->  higher gaslimits safer; similar gains to Bitcoin NG ideas
* Allows committees, which are needed for sharding (incl dank-)
* Finality -> higher gaslimits safer

@WilsonCusack As for "why do utilitarianism at all instead of just following a list of rules?", well we have to judge which rules are worth keeping or strengthening or even inventing, and which rules belong in the same dumpster fire as, say, "sodomy is bad"

@WilsonCusack Mill would say this does not contradict utilitarianism, because the really bright "no nukes" rule is a social mechanism that as a whole prevents lots of suffering, and there's huge value in presrerving the sanctity of the rule.

@WilsonCusack One big place where absolutism seems to have value is adversarial social situations. There's good reasons to get more upset at 10k dying from a tiny nuke than 100k dying from conventional bombing, for example.

@WilsonCusack Right but putting your foot down and saying X always supersedes Y also easily has big unkown consequences.

Mill's approach feels to me like "of course you don't calculate the good every time, you follow good rules, but be mindful of exceptions"

@WilsonCusack I definitely believe that viewpoints that say "X is bad no matter the circumstance" are almost always wrong, and are an excellent example of why we need formal moral philosophy instead of just trusting reflexes that appeal to us emotionally.

People who criticize "utilitarianism" are often actually criticizing something quite different, like coldness or expediency.

John Stuart Mill himself wrote quite a lot about the distinction in his original work in 1863. The whole thing is worth reading:

@migowski @devonzuegel It probably applies to the medians too, but it definitely applies to the average.

Toy example: three buses with {4, 1, 1} passengers.

Average bus: avg(4, 1, 1) = (4+1+1) / 3 = 2 passengers

Average passenger's bus: avg(4, 4, 4, 4, 1, 1) = (4+4+4+4+1+1) / 6 = 3 passengers
@devonzuegel Ah yes, the "the average bus-passenger is on a bus that's much more full than the average bus" effect. One of my favorite mathematical paradoxes.

Summary: the "things we ultimately want" aren't individual or collective, but "strategies for achieving them" can be either one or a mix of the two.

Even strategies for protecting freedom can be collective (defending against aggressive wars, to give an obvious example).

Another confusing one is "economic growth", which often gets construed as individualistic, but there are plenty of collective, and occasionally even freedom-sacrificing, ways of making it happen.

(Economic growth is really important BTW. See https://t.co/DNz8p7e65I )

Freedom really is more of a meta-goal, basically about preserving your ability to choose which of the other goals you value more at a particular time and place.

(Though some will say autonomy is also to some extent intrinsically important to happiness)

The "freedom vs safety" discussion is confused because often the issue is really "convenience vs safety", or other terminal goals vs safety. But our culture (imo wrongly) denigrates "mere convenience", so people end up appealing to freedom instead.

https://t.co/TZCZ5mvixl

Health similarly isn't a private or public good, it just is. But there are ways of improving our health that are individual, and there are ways of improving our health that only work if very large groups of people cooperate to make it happen.

Individual convenience-seeking: buying a phone, which lets you do lots of computing and social stuff on the go.

Collective convenience-seeking: the basic research needed to invent the phone and make it possible to produce and distribute.

By terminal goals I *roughly* mean things like convenience, safety, fun, enjoyment, status, love, health...

Terminal goals aren't "individual" or "collective", they just are. What *is* individual or collective are the strategies for achieving these ends.

I've been thinking about *why* this is true, and I might have an explanation. Basically, I think it comes down to a confusion between terminal goals ("the things we ultimately want") and our strategies for achieving them...

Rhetorical tip: you can often frame either side of a debate as being individualist or collectivist.

Example:

"Instead of worrying so much about our individual safety, we should focus more on our collective need to have a rich and enjoyable shared life that's worth living for"

@joshgans @glenweyl I definitely think there are ways of achieving these goals that break things and ways that don't break things. Pairwise-matching feels on the safe side; if you try to lie to look uncorrelated and win big on one matching opportunity, you're missing out on lots of other matches.

@joshgans @glenweyl > don‚Äôt we want truthful voting of preferences?

We definitely do, though cooperative game theory tells us that once you move away from (unrealistic) individual-choice assumptions achieving the optimum is often impossible, so we have to be more humble in what the goals are.

@glenweyl @joshgans So if you normally vote perfectly in lockstep with 1000 other people, but then one day you go vote something totally separate from them, that vote gets full consideration just like a vote of someone whose votes are independent every single day.

@glenweyl @joshgans Also, the voting mechanisms we're talking about aren't discounting *people*. There's no "you seem similar to this other group, so you're a sheep, 0.25 votes for you" mechanic. It's operating on the level of voting patterns...

@glenweyl @joshgans And so explicit per-country votes are a crude countermeasure that at least attempts to compensate for these pressures.

"One vote per country" should not run the world, but "N votes for an N-person country" also shouldn't.

@glenweyl @joshgans I would even say that economies of scale in extraction tend to be larger than economies of scale in production; that is, the optimal country (or company) size for peacefully doing useful stuff is lower than the optimal size for extracting rent by being a tough guy.
@glenweyl @joshgans ... to the point where a 100 million person country has significantly more power than a 100 million person geographic area split between 10 countries.

@glenweyl @joshgans To name one specific example, the concept of each country having one vote at the UN is something that I used to find really stupid, but recently less so. The reason is that larger countries already have lots of other ways to exert excessive concentrated influence...

I would say that in general the biggest evil is not accountability or unaccountability, but *imbalanced accountability* - being accountable for some types of consequences but not others.

This creates a clear imbalance, where people target only the thing that is being measured.

Anon culture is about having less accountability, with the goal of allowing people to authentically speak their minds.

As an anon, you don't get negative personal consequences for saying things others dislike, but you also miss out on lots of positive personal consequences.

"Accountability" is viewed by most people as a virtue, but it's interesting to look at cases where *lack of accountability* is an explicit goal of some system.

Examples:

* Voting (secret ballot)
* Juries
* Tenure
* Anonymous complaints
* Privacy norms/rules/laws

BTW this includes a definite-optimist attitude to crypto. Hence my focus on:

* Public goods funding
* Social recovery / multisig wallets
* Reputation systems (could help a lot to fight scams!)
* PoS (solves energy issues)
* Scaling (reduces fees, makes non-financial apps viable)

I do think that we need less indefinite optimism and more definite optimism - less relying on magic forces to make things better and more concerted efforts to identify specific great things that could be built and build them.

Of course, there are big problems. But to me, the problems do not add up to a generalized "case against technology". They are sector-specific problems with sector-specific solutions.

AI friendliness work. Biodefense. Decentralized tech. Treaties against some really nasty stuff.

Each of those items is a Really. Big Deal.

I even think that if you give people the option of going back to a world where the technology is rewound to what it was in 2000, many would consider *that* a dystopia. I know I would!
Cryptocurrency too: it has made international money transfer easier and given many people access to robust savings tools (DAI and USDC).

* Globally democratized access to culture
* Greater information flow in authoritarian regimes (despite the censorship)
* Convenience and safety from electronic documents
* Massively simplified logistics of traveling
* Translation software (also automated captioning etc)

* Instant global accessibility of often frontier-level knowledge
* Covid vaccines
* Remote work
* Remote friendship
* Urban navigation (smartphone maps)
* Falling prices of clothing and many other physical items
* Solar power
* Very-low-cost entertainment

Some people responded "but technology HAS had few upsides and many downsides!"

I definitely agree there are important problems. But I also think much of the pessimism is narrative, not reality.

I guess the conclusion is, peacekeeping and cooperation-seeking needs to be an explicit effort rather than peace being an assumed default.
As @balajis loves to say, "live and let live" can be upgraded to "win and help win".

BTW I strongly agree with the sentiment.

Like, even selfishly speaking, a nuclear bunker could stop a nuke from killing me directly, but it can't stop the nuclear war from destroying the scientific ecosystem that I'm counting on to cure aging before I succumb to it in ~60 years.

I do think that many people disagree less than they think. Eg. @glenweyl @balajis fight a lot, but when I talk to them, both have a strong "we're all in this together" attitude: this century either all of humanity rises or all of humanity falls.

That's a key point of agreement!

One thing is that I think people working in any of the "big movements" should more actively think about offering olive branches: how can you make what you're building 10% more palatable to the other side?

But we also have to keep the peace between the big groups, and navigate the reality that many of these movements really do contain, in their worst versions, threats to each other's visions of a bright future for humanity.

Another example might be the ethereum identity space (@signinwitheth + ENS + POAPs + maybe soon SBTs).

These smaller spaces can help create new optimistic visions for the future *and* create something that people can be part of without also being part of the financialized cruft. https://t.co/RCNI2XlSnt

One path is to focus more on the newer and smaller sub-movements, that are more opinionated about their values. The "regen finance" movement in ethereum (big credit to @gitcoin @proofofhumanity and now @optimismPBC, arguably @MolochDAO too) is one great example.
I'm inclined to believe it's some of all of those causes, and they are interrelated. But what can we *do* about this?

Explanation 5: we have social media now and social media rewards negativity.

(If true, I think this is unhealthy and we should just fight it head-on, but less sure *how* to do that)

Explanation 4: today's culture is just in general more driven by fear of dystopia rather than excitement about positive visions, and so everyone's first question is now "will your thing create a dystopia?"

(If true, I think this is unhealthy and we should just fight it head-on)

As Cory mentioned, crypto was at first just decentralization enthusiasts, but now there's also various types of "money people".

This is an inevitable part of becoming bigger. In non-financial movements too, various classes of normies and often soon grifters move in over time.
Explanation 3: idealistic small movements easily lose their idealism and become mixed in with other energies once they become big, and those other energies more easily lead to negative stuff.

Also related is the "dense jungle" phenomenon I talk about here:

https://t.co/iUc7VYLglA

The internet naturally puts everything distance 1 away from everything else. This too makes live-and-let-live harder.

One important factor is that all of those movements *got much bigger* in the last decade. When something is small, even if you don't like it, it's not a threat, so it's easy to live-and-let-live. When everything is big, more competition, so more incentive to point out problems.
But complaining about the phenomenon won't fix it. Need to understand it.

This all makes me feel very sad. My natural temperament has always been that I want to be part of all the good-guy teams and bring them together. But now many of these teams that I've grown up loving are attacking each other and considering each other harmful.

Other examples of this:

* Maximalism in crypto
* Many libertarians turning against {democracy | immigration | cosmopolitan morality...}
* The rabidly anti-vegetable types
* The "woke vs rationalist" mini-internet-war last year
* The hostile responses here https://t.co/jkVtB9C9zy

See https://t.co/Bq6wzKcXam for @doctorow's explanation of his views.

Cory's devcon speech has some specific concerns about financialization.

But it feels like there are deeper causes. The crypto vs tech-left divide is not the only divide; *all* the teams are divided.

Today, we see @doctorow signing onto a letter advocating regulating crypto more harshly, which is upsetting and confusing a lot of crypto advocates because many looked up to his vision and saw themselves as fellow travelers.

Many libertarians were excited about direct democracy.

PorcFest (big libertarian event) had lots of carnivore *and* vegan food.

Rick @Falkvinge bridged Bitcoin and the Pirate Party.

Lots of blockchain people and "open source community" people saw each other as natural allies.

A big difference between the "new idealistic movement" scene 10-15 years ago vs today is that back then it felt possible to be on all the good-guy teams at the same time. Today, much more adversarial thinking and conflict.

I've been trying to understand.. where to from here?

Quick math explanation:

This is a blinded proof of membership. We want to prove `P(z) = y` without revealing `z` (but `y` is public). Normally, a proof is `Q = (P - y) / (X - z)`. Here, we instead do `Q = (P - y) / (rX - rz)` to blind `z`.

And prove that `z` is a root of unity. https://t.co/H91JYbA60c

Contradiction between my desire to be a positive-sum mediator figure that can be everyone's friend and my desire to stand strongly with good against evil those times when true evil is what we face.

Contradiction between my desire for crypto to grow beyond finance and my realization that finance (incl payments+SoV) is still by far the most successful category of crypto apps, *especially* among third-world residents, human rights activists and vulnerable people generally.

Contradiction between my dislike of many modern financial blockchain "applications" ($3M monkeys etc), and my grudging appreciation for the fact that that stuff is a big part of what keeps the crypto economy running and pays for all my favorite cool DAO/governance experiments.

Contradiction between my desire to see more diversity in interesting *cultures* and my realization that maintaining a culture that's distinct from the mainstream seems to often require *some* kind of insanity or artificial barrier or similar thing that I ideologically dislike.

Contradiction between my desire to see more countries adopting radical policy experiments (eg. crypto countries!) and my realization that the governments most likely to go all the way on such things are more likely to be centralized and not friendly to diversity internally.

Contradiction between my love for things like decentralization and democracy, and my realization that in practice I agree with intellectual elites more than "the people" on many (though definitely far from all) specific policy issues.

Contradiction between my desire to see Ethereum become an L1 that can survive truly extreme circumstances and my realization that many key apps on Ethereum already rely on far more fragile security assumptions than anything we consider acceptable in Ethereum protocol design.

Contradiction between my preference for reducing reliance on individuals and trying to build fixed systems that can stand the test of time and my appreciation of "live players" and their role in helping the world move forward.
Thread: some still open contradictions in my thoughts and my values, that I have been thinking about but still don't feel like I've fully resolved.

@MTabarrok Proof by induction is easy to reword as proof by contradiction.

"P(0) is true, P(x) implies P(x+1), therefore P(any +ve int) is true"

Becomes

"suppose P(x) is not always true. Let z be smallest x where P(z) is false. But then P(z-1) is true, so P(z) is true, contradiction!"

@rohitalmelkar Yes. It should be computationally infeasible to discover x where f(x) can't be computed, or (x, y) where x != y but f(x) = f(y).

(Or if the construction has *other* defects, eg. z where f_inv(z) can't be computed, those should also be hard to find)

@jasonhuan_ By definition, a function from [0...2^256-1] to [0...2^256 - 2] can't be truly invertible everywhere; there has to be some x where f(x) can't be computed, or some f(x) = f(y) collision. I want these unavoidable exceptions to be computationally infeasible to discover.

@domothy A really efficient solution could actually significantly simplify Verkle trees, erasure codes and many other constructions in ethereum, by making 32-byte chunks one-to-one mappable to F_p elements.
@zkproofs Either one.

Cryptography problem: make an invertible, easy-in-both-directions function from [0...2^256 - 1] to [0...2^256 - 2] (or more generally, -k for small k) where the exceptions to the invertibility are computationally infeasible to find.

Real life is similar, except (i) the "perfect-play" strategy is even more obviously intractable (you have to simulate the universe), and (ii) even the goals are less well-defined.

You can't just keep telling a player to correct for biases and eventually end up with "as close as you can get to perfect play". At some point, you have to actually add content and depth to the strategy. And that content and depth will inevitably involve opinionated choices.

You may even learn to avoid an entire list of specific biases that you know about, but there will always be *some way* to describe how your algorithm diverges from the perfect strategy that is forever out of reach to us mere polynomial-time mortals.

Because we don't have the computational power to do perfect play, that algorithm will inevitably involve simplifications of the world, and opinionated choices of what intermediate abstractions to reason about.
Sure, you can say "Alice overvalues material relative to position", "Bob cares too much about castling", etc. But you also have to talk about the *content* in the player's algorithm.

Chess players, even at the top, generally use some combination of explicit strategy and illegible "instinct". But it's not useful to describe their strategies by talking about them as having particular biases separating them from some theoretical ideal.

If we had an infinitely-powerful supercomputer, we actually could search through all ~10^120 possibilities down the game tree and give a theoretically optimal move.

But in reality we don't have anything close to such capabilities. So what can we do?

@PatrickAlphaC @glenweyl @theshteves @JonCo11ins One really important mathematical fact to get your head around with QV is that it's optimal to make votes that sum to zero. If your votes sum to x > 0, you can shift them down and they'll be equally effective but cost fewer credits.

The UI could even enforce sum = 0 if desired.

@glenweyl @PatrickAlphaC @theshteves @JonCo11ins The arguments about cognitive costs disadvantaging small candidates may well be real.

Such issues are why I came up with https://t.co/KmXDXmszcG , and I really hope someone takes this idea and develops it further!

@glenweyl @PatrickAlphaC @theshteves @JonCo11ins The one-sentence explanation is that negative votes are key: if A and B are "the most realistic" candidates, and you like A, then you'll vote +5 A -5 B (and people who think the opposite about A vs B cancel you out), and on net that doesn't push C further back relative to A and B

18. Many are inclined to dismiss this whole shape rotator and wordcel thing because it came from 4chan, and "everyone knows" 4chan is icky and hateful or whatever.

But I take it seriously. It's a new internet-native culture trying to understand the human world on its own terms.

17. BTW apparently the way noun declension works in this internet language is that if you respect someone being called a -cel, then the ending becomes -chad, so perhaps we should be talking about theorychads (and even wordchads)?

16. It's fascinating how the two axes seem to imply each other:

Pure tinkering is fast and effective, but it is unprincipled, so lacks large-scale legitimacy, so can only cooperate through centralization

Theorycel thinking is slower, but well-suited for decentralization

15. See also: Peter Thiel's idea that "crypto is libertarian, AI is communist"

https://t.co/SygGPLLQre

14. So to summarize, I do think crypto is heavy on shape rotating and "crypto is theorycels who have accomplished nothing but scams" vastly undersells what crypto is situated to accomplish, but the crypto vs AI dichotomy also does point to something really important.

13. But crypto isn't just team theorycel. Crypto is certainly very theorycel compared to AI (and as I argue above, that's its *advantage*), but it also does a lot of shape rotation (which is crypto's advantage compared to much more purely wordcel-driven trad institutions)

12. And why I ultimately do think liberal democracies are much more well-suited to be the center of a "world order" than autocracies. A world where the center is a centralized black box is scary.

(But democracies do need to actually follow principles to keep their legitimacy)

11. Theory is transparent and legible to outsiders, tinkering is opaque. Hence why crypto (the blockchains, not the applications on top of them) really has gained quite a bit of public trust, while AI has largely failed at achieving that goal.

10. To be clear, I think there are important good things that come out of taking theorycel aesthetics seriously, and people who don't suffer for it. A really big one is credible neutrality:

https://t.co/Eu3IYjAs5y

9. One interesting parallel is @MacaesBruno's "black box" as a metaphor for how philosophy works in China, and why AI is attractive there. Very low on theorycel aesthetics, high on "just keep shape rotating until it seems to work"

https://t.co/TZk0LcGuRP

https://t.co/Fal1ML4f7P https://t.co/coyHqEuBTW

8. Meanwhile, AI is the exact opposite. It really does produce wonders, but we can't explain how it works, and there's far more unprincipled tinkering than theory.

And to be fair, the unprincipled approach does cause problems that crypto doesn't have!

https://t.co/J3ZgI7JXmo

7. Crypto thinking about decentralization is similar. It's all about avoiding ugly unprincipled exceptions (in a centralized system, who gets to be the center?)

Focus is on proving hard unconditional security models (eg. secure unless >= 1/3 of stake is malicious)

6. The core instinct is: we need a formal system of rights and limits that treats everyone equally and doesn't make unprincipled exceptions. You can't enslave or steal, so the government should not be able to enslave (conscription) or steal (taxation) either.

5. There's also something deeper going on. Zeroing in now on the phrase "theorycel aesthetic sensibilities".

A lot of early crypto ideology was inspired by libertarianism, eg. Bastiat, Mises, Rothbard... which cares *a lot* about theorycel aesthetic vision of equality.

@andrej_muzevic This is called being pragmatic about freedom ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Different from being dogmatic!
Paradox of diversity: if every organization within society must fully reflect the diversity of that society's members, then there can be no diversity *between* organizations in that society.

Paradox of authority: you can't be consistent and believe authority too much, because different authorities frequently have low opinions of each other. So either you end up half-skeptical toward all, or you (intentionally or not) make your own choice of which authority to follow.

Paradox of freedom: you can't be consistent and too dogmatic about freedom. Eventually you see how in the real world, many people often give up their freedom for little in return. So you either accept their judgement, or decide you know better than them what's good for them...

In 2021 I mostly stuck to a self-imposed twitter quarantine, only using this site to post links to my long-form content.

Q1: in retrospect, do you think this was a good idea?
Q2: what should I do in 2022?

(replies followees-only to ensure quality)

* On tech, I was more often right on abstract ideas than on production software dev issues. Had to learn to understand the latter over time
* I have a deeper appreciation now of the need for even more simplicity than I thought we needed

* I did have good instincts early on for avoiding the craziest parts of bitcoin maximalist thinking. A couple early mistakes, but I corrected quickly
* But X being wrong does not imply that any specific rebellion against X will go well! Yet another way in which politics is hard

Conclusions:

* My thinking about politics and large-scale human organization was more naive then. Too focused on simple and complete formal models; I did not appreciate challenges of culture and https://t.co/vLCznr6Da5 then; I do now.

12. A more detailed opinion on stablecoins from 2014: https://t.co/RwRx4HVjEL

A big part of this post tried to tackle the question of whether or not you could have a stablecoin without oracles, by using blockchain data (eg. PoW diff) as a pseudo-price-oracle.

A lot correct (basically predicted "defi"), though incentivized file storage + compute hasn't taken off that much (yet?), and of course I completely missed NFTs.

Today, I would call BCH mostly a failure. My main takeaway: communities formed around a rebellion, even if they have a good cause, often have a hard time long term, because they value bravery over competence and are united around resistance rather than a coherent way forward.

5. I should also add that the core *idea* of sharding has survived unscathed.

Blockchain 1.0: each node downloads everything, have consensus
BitTorrent: each node downloads only a few things, but no consensus
Ideal: BitTorrent-like efficiency but with blockchain-like consensus

4. Though I 100% stand by my comment that "the internet of money should not cost more than 5 cents per transaction". That was the goal in 2017, and it's still the goal now. It's precisely why we're spending so much time working on scalability.

Side B wants to support X but feels discomfort about violating its principles (interests usually beat principles), and side A wants to oppose X but similarly feels discomfort. I claim that this pattern is very common in tribal conflicts.

@SBF_Alameda Only the sequencer would actually "process" txs and compute the state. The key rule is: a sequencer *must* include *all* batchers that the collectors produced. The goal is that even if sequencers are highly centralized, as long as collectors are not, sequencers cannot censor.

@SBF_Alameda The idea here is basically an anti-censorship tactic. Have two classes of block producers. The lower-performance class ("collectors") would just make batches of transactions; you could have many in parallel. The higher-perf class ("sequencers") would combine batches into blocks.

@SBF_Alameda The thing I forgot to say that I could add is also the longer-term situation: if you want to go even higher than 100k TPS (1-5m?), a single-threaded chain requires you to go beyond even a high-performance desktop, whereas a sharded system can just scale out by adding more nodes.

@__padpad @juliagalef Trustless trusted setup generator for all other schemes: obfuscate a program that contains a key k, and accepts an input program p, and outputs p(k) as long as there's a proof that p(k) does not reveal k

[ok I admit that last part is going to be hard to implement]

@__padpad @juliagalef Black box fields: obfuscate the programs `out = encrypt(decrypt(in1) + decrypt(in2))`, `out = encrypt(decrypt(in1) * decrypt(in2))` and the same for (-, /, =)

Note: can leave out the / to get black box rings instead

@__padpad @juliagalef ZK-SNARK: generate priv/pub keypair (k, K), obfuscate the program "accept (c, x), c=circuit, x=input_to_circuit, as input, check if c(x) = 1, if so, sign (hash(c), x) with k", and verify by just checking the signature with K.

This gives a 32-byte-long SNARK potentially (!!)

@__padpad @juliagalef Yeah, it's really easy to build any other crypto primitive from obfuscation:

Public key encryption: use a symmetric-key encryption scheme (easy to build one with hashes), publish the obfuscated encryptor

@mmariani22 ETH also has that rule.

Eth rewards go:

* Down by 0.5% if 1% more people stake
* Up by 1% if 1% more of those people who are staking stay online

@gtomo1986 Current projections for PoW rewards:

Now: stay the same
Mid-2021: miners no longer get most txfee revenue due to EIP 1559 (bulk of fees get burned instead)
When the merge happens: no more PoW
So rewards a couple percentage points below the theoretical max are to be expected... but not too far below, as there's a high incentive for all stakers to try their best to be online.
This rule was added to discourage validators from engaging in censorship, selfish mining and other adversarial tactics against other validators.
One important clarification: your rewards are multiplied by the percentage of validators that are online (eg. if 90% of validators are online, everyone's rewards are multiplied by 0.9x)

The magic numbers in the above code:

31556926 = seconds per year
384 = seconds per epoch
31556926 / 384 = epochs per year
64 = BASE_REWARD_FACTOR
31622 = sqrt(gwei per ETH)
x -> math.exp(x)-1 to account for compounding

Quick python code for computing staking reward rates from total ETH staked:

> def calc_annual_reward(total_staked):
   return math.exp(31556926 / 384 * 64 / 31622 / total_staked ** 0.5) - 1
 
> calc_annual_reward(524288)
0.25822791207
> calc_annual_reward(1000000)
0.18095530109

@_ArnaudS_ I'm definitely very in favor of *local* empowered executives:

https://t.co/SvvxfjOwPe

To clarify, by "global" empowered executive I mean the idea that the governance mechanism gives a small group widespread powers over the whole system. The opposite is a *local* empowered executive, eg. a quadratic funding system providing $1m to someone who manages a team
I think the fact that optimal governance of agile things and optimal governance of quasi-automata are different problems is missing from a lot of governance discussions.

Thomas Sowell talks about this a lot: there is an inherent tradeoff between flexibility/agility on one side, and stability/dependability on the other side. Different systems benefit from being at different points in this tradeoff space.

There are different kinds of governance problems. Sometimes, the thing being governed is *meant to be* agile, other times it's meant to be a quiet quasi-automaton, more like a court than a legislature. Eg. quadratic funding is more like the latter than the former.

One important issue is that people often want decentralization precisely because they want a system that has strong resistance to changing in controversial ways. "Empowered executives" are a perfect tool to circumvent that, so they could be counterproductive to that end...

This is an interesting thread worth reading, though I disagree with the implication that a global "empowered executive" is necessarily the correct solution; it feels like it ignores why people want *decentralized orgs* and not just *better orgs*. I think it's context-dependent...

@insideNiMA The slide without the fourth point appeared earlier in the presentation too. And the fourth point is only relevant in an architecture where apps do move to base-layer sharded execution.

PS. @lightclients has a compelling take that rollups and sharding-of-tx-execution are actually *very similar* mechanisms. But this gets into more complicated theory and is further away from concrete consequences to applications...

https://t.co/bfesa2zkVR

So it's not "rollups instead of sharding", it's "rollups on top of sharding". That said, rollups are already here or coming soon even before sharding, and rollups without sharding still offer that 100x increase in throughput. So get on a rollup today!

But the roadmap has an interesting unintended artefact: sharded applications by themselves need phase 2. But sharded rollups only need phase 1, because rollups use the chain only for data, not for computation. So we will have all the tools we need for 6400x throughput quite soon!

Currently, we have ~15-45 TPS. Rollups offer a ~100x increase in throughput. Sharding offers a ~64x increase. These two stack multiplicatively; rollups *on top of* sharding offer a ~6400x (!!) increase in throughput.

The original ETH2 roadmap was created with 3 phases:

0. PoS (this is the one that's coming very soon)
1. Sharding of data, but not of computation (that is, the sharded chain will *include* ~2 MB/sec of data, but it will just be dumb data blobs, not txs)
2. Sharded tx processing

@jadler0 @OffchainLabs @optimismPBC So with larger n, the effect of batching actually *decreases* (as log(k) becomes smaller relative to log(n))

@semenov_roman_ Rollups would have internal "gas limits" on transactions, where the gas costs would be based on the cost of a fraud proof of that transaction. But it's not a 1:1 ratio; you only need a 32-byte (512-gas) intermediate state root for every 10M of L2 gas.
And in the somewhat longer term, sharding from ethereum 2.0.

Conclusion: the only solution to high tx fees is scaling. Tether, Gitcoin and other apps are doing the right thing by migrating to ZK rollups today. I'm excited about the soon-upcoming optimistic rollups that will generalize rollup scaling to full EVM contracts.

Sharding, on the other hand, increases the capacity of the base layer by ~100x. This could lead to a 100x decrease in fees, though realistically in the long term it would not decrease quite as much because people's interest in using ethereum (ie. demand) would also increase

In a rollup-heavy ecosystem, on-chain gas fees would remain the same, and 465 gwei may even become the norm, but most transactions would be happening inside rollups, where actual fees paid by users would be hundreds of times lower.

The better solution is drastic increases in scalability through (i) rollups, and (ii) sharding. Optimistic and ZK rollups can increase capacity from ~15 tx/sec to ~3000 tx/sec by doing most of the transaction processing on layer 2.

EIP-2929, published today, would increase gas costs of some particularly sensitive operations, making it safer to increase gas limits. But this would only be a tiny short term mitigation; decreasing fees from 465 to 372 gwei would not solve the problem.

https://t.co/UBdiNVnZNo

However, increasing capacity is hard to do safely. Ethereum nodes are already running near their limits and there is always the risk of DoS attacks that are much slower to process than regular blocks, slowing the chain to a crawl. Higher gaslimits would exacerbate this.

Some very rough math from me years ago suggests the elasticity actually is ~1, ie. a 1.17x increase in gaslimit implies roughly a 1.17x decrease in fees.

https://t.co/W8UAdk46ri

So what does work? Increasing transaction capacity. The fee level at which there exist 15m gas worth of willing transaction senders is higher than the level at which there exist 12.5m gas worth of willing transaction senders.

And what's the equilibrium? Well, it's the place where people are actually, once again, paying 465 gwei (and therefore the number in the transaction becomes 2325 gwei and the EF/Vitalik now have to pay the 1860 gwei difference instead of using that money to scale ethereum).

Why? Suppose that this happens. Suddenly, when everyone is selecting "465" as their txfee, they are no longer *actually* paying 465 gwei, rather, they are paying 93 gwei.  And there are many more people willing to pay 93 gwei than at 465 gwei. Hence, people start bidding up...

Here's a common class of "solution" that I hear to the high txfee problem: why not have (the protocol | the Ethereum foundation | Vitalik) just refund 80% of everyone's fees? But if you understand what I said above, you'll quickly see that this does not work.

The remaining transactors would see that blocks are partially empty, so if they lower their fees they would still get included. Hence, everyone would start lowering their fees. How low would they go? 465 gwei.
Similarly, imagine everyone was sending transactions with 1000 gwei. A bunch of people would no longer find it worthwhile to send transactions, so they would drop out.

So what would happen? There would be more demand than there is space, so people would start bidding higher and higher txfees. How high would txfees go until enough people drop out that the remaining users make up only 12.5 million gas? Well, we know the answer: 465 gwei.

Suppose we were in a world identical to today, but where everyone was sending transactions with 100 gwei. At the 100 gwei level, everyone who would be sending txs today would still be sending txs, but there would also be many more who are willing to send at 100, but not at 465.

First of all, why is the gasprice currently 465 gwei? Why isn't it 1000 gwei, or 100 gwei?

The reason is: 465 gwei happens to be the current level at which demand (the number of transactions people are willing to send) equals supply (12.5 million gas of tx space in each block).
A quick thread on supply and demand economics, and why certain "naive" solutions to high gas prices won't work. https://t.co/lmmyx0x8vL

@astrojams1 Two textboxes:

* Contract you want to recover
* What new key to set it to

And an "approve" button.

Also of course a "publish contract to chain" button if the contract is not yet on chain.

This is the most standards-compliant and backward-compatible possible way to do social recovery: allow recovery-friendly wallets to set *one* recovery address, and that recovery address can have arbitrary logic, which is not published to chain until it's actually used.

The multisig itself should ideally have some easy UI. The goal of this is to make privacy-preserving social recovery easier: you would only need to specify one recoverer address, and that address's logic would not be visible onchain unless it actually gets used.

@VeChainBrothers @vechainoracle Oh I agree having a non politically controlled currency will change a lot of things about the world. But I don't see "defunding governments by taking away their inflation spending" as being the channel through which that happens

@alaskarobotics People have definitely tried making global-UBI coins and the like; though a big challenge there is that we don't have identity models powerful enough to make those secure. I would actually say the work by brightid and the like could be one path toward fixing that...

@alaskarobotics I've definitely seen quite a few actual people in third-world countries who work remotely for first-world companies and use crypto to get the money back home to their families much more efficiently than they can with fiat tools.

(I recognize that some people in the thread I linked to above said things other than "govts having 10-20% less funding will lead to utopia", I definitely commend those with the more diverse viewpoints)

Rather, things I focus on are:

* Freedom to transact+organize for marginalized people
* Escaping the tyrannies of weaponized interdepedence https://t.co/UsmbQBjTqT
* Minimizing excessive power of gatekeepers
* Freedom of exit

etc etc

And there's plenty that governments can effectively tax even in a hypothetical extreme world of zero financial surveillance; property, physical sales, transactions in large organizations, natural resources, lots of urban anti-congestion regs can be turned into Pigovian taxes...

My theory is more moderate. Money printing is only a small portion of governments' budgets, and furthermore it's very naive to think that if govts were forced to shrink their revenue by 10-20% it's the militaries that go first.

It's interesting how in the last few weeks I've argued with both pro-BTC *and* anti-BTC people who think BTC will utterly cripple nation state funding (pro-BTC ppl wanting to defund the militaries), while I disagree with both: I just don't think it will have that kind of effect.

@DefundTheState_ @fnietom The point is that there's no way for different users to get different levels of security, as it's all one chain.

Waiting for more confirmations does give you more security, but arguably needing to wait really long already is a failure mode.

@fnietom Once you adopt this perspective, you quickly realize that the two things (demand for space, and demand for security) are not necessarily coupled with each other, and so it's very possible for one to be insufficient to cover the other.

@fnietom So that's when you realize that the blockchain is more like a very minimalistic and automated *government*, where the only public good provided (network security) is paid for by a tax (or rather, cap-and-trade system) imposed on another resource (scarce block space).

@fnietom ... instead, people who care more about *urgency* pay higher txfees. So the price being paid  is completely independent of the quality of product received, because on-chain everyone receives the same security as everyone else.

@fnietom Simple thought experiment to show that the fee market is NOT a regular "market where users pay for their own security": if that were how it works, then users who care more about security would pay higher txfees. But that's not what happens ...
@fnietom Markets fail to efficiently manage the tradeoff between externalities all the time....

@hasufl I think state provision is also a challenging problem, but history is low-hanging fruit and relatively safe to deploy new solutions in because relatively few apps depend on history (though rollups do!). Hence, history seems like a good place to start first, then move on to state.

@realLedgerwatch @AFDudley0 @cyber_hokie Definitely great work, though it's not the same thing as what I'm talking about, which is a cryptoeconomic marketplace for on-demand querying of logs by specific topics, transactions by hash (or by account), etc.
@_prestwich @wekabot I'm assuming clients know the current state; I'm advocating layer-2 infrastructure specifically for learning about *history* here.

@_prestwich @wekabot I'm introducing a dependency on the *present* state to the security of the query about *history*. The fraud proof would need to provide a Merkle path from the missing log all the way into the current state.

@wekabot Fraud-proving that a set given by someone else is not complete is easy.

I'm explicitly proposing leaning heavily on cryptoeconomics for this.

There's certainly quite a few people who have thought about such things, even implemented prototypes, etc, but this seems like an important area where we'd benefit substantially from ~5x more effort being put into it.
Additionally, notice that in eth2 when the network is sharded, infrastructures of this kind basically become mandatory if we want to avoid dapp UIs all relying on centralized providers (ü§Æ)

This has two key benefits to ethereum:

1. Clients could stop storing history themselves, and only store state (~5x storage size decrease)
2. Dapps could get more gas-efficient (many dapps are suboptimal gaswise today because they put things in storage to read them more easily)
The important thing is that this could+should be fully decentralized neutral architecture, and being a provider should be permissionless.

Payment could be done through state channels: clients would randomly choose a provider, open a channel with them, and pay through the channel for each request.

If a provider fails to respond quickly, the client can just switch to another provider.

One example is logs:

1. Client sends message "I want all historical logs for topic X"
2. Provider replies back with logs + Merkle proofs
3. Client re-broadcasts provider's response; if the provider missed a log their deposit can get slashed

This could be done for txs too...
One important problem in ethereum that has not yet seen enough love is decentralized marketplaces for providing historical information (logs, txs... basically anything other than current state).

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat @_prestwich you happy with this? Seems like it at least theoretically allows clients to generate withdrawal branches efficiently purely from on-chain data.
@LtColLinkarski @_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Thinkpad T495
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Oh sorry the scanning would be O(t * log(N)), not O(N), as you can sort the state update records in each batch to let the client binary search.

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat .... to generate the part of the branch below the middle of the tree. So then a consumer laptop would be sufficient to generate withdrawal branches for even ultra-high-capacity rollups.

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Oh sorry continuing the above: you can design a rollup which periodically requires publishing on chain the sqrt(N) hashes in the middle of the state tree. So computing *a single branch* would still require an O(N) scanning process, but only O(sqrt(N)) hashing...
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat My consumer laptop is handling the ethereum L1 just fine!
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat (to scale past that you could just.... have multiple rollups)
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Doable on a consumer laptop even for a rollup in the hundreds of TPS.

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Actually, I conceded in one area too quickly. The process of reconstructing the state is just  processing all the deltas on chain and then building a merkle tree at the end. It's super fast: no sig verifications, log(n) times less hashing than it took to create the tree.
@_prestwich @BenDiFrancesco @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat You.... know that's a deep mischaracterization of my argument.

@ercwl @_prestwich @aliatiia_ @DZack23 @barrywhitehat How is 1-of-N honesty big? It's the that model you rely on every day to protect against malicious bugs in client code, and that's way more tenuous - you'd probably need 50 honest bugcheckers for security, here you just need one honest RU node in the sea of all nodes out there.

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat What about a delay of 2 weeks? Are state channels also "trusted" then? Any state channel construction also has bad exceptional case behavior, is that also not scaling?

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Also you haven't yet responded to the fact that all this is only an issue if N of N honest RU validators disappear as the same time, which is.... vastly less likely than a specific party becoming dishonest/hacked.

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat "at any time" sounds very misleading. Remember that it's totally okay if it takes them 2 months to source the hardware, just means they don't get their coins for 2 months.
@JaEsf @_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat I've been trying to advance the vocabulary to "1-of-1 vs 1-of-N trust models"!
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat "there exists at least one guy with a powerful computer that will let you use it if you pay" seems fine enough.

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Why do you need to already have an account? You can setup the account as whatever cloud computing service you want only when you need to. No need to even think about it until/unless the exceptional case actually happens.
@_prestwich @JaEsf @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat See https://t.co/I0AfcqYMu1

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat A delay of as long as it takes you to temporarily rent computing power from EC2.

Also in a rollup you can force a withdrawal in a way that prevents the chain from growing unless the operator withdraws for you so the "chain goes faster than you" thing doesn't apply.

@_prestwich @JaEsf @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat But if you're forced to make only 2 buckets, where one contains "no trust assumptions" and the other contains "trust a specific party", a 1-of-N trust model (where anyone can join the N) belongs in the first bucket, not the second, because it's closer to that scenario.

@_prestwich @JaEsf @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat I think putting all possible assumptions about behavior of nodes that you do not control under the umbrella of "trust" reduces precision, not increases it.

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat If you do that then an exceptional scenario (really just Infura getting hacked) could trick you into thinking into thinking something wrong about the blockchain state until you run the node yourself.

Here, N of N nodes breaking means you only suffer a delay on availability.
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat But you only need to get that hardware in the exceptional case!
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Things breaking in the worst case is obviously not OK. But we're talking about you just having to run a powerful node as a worst case.

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat (And I also refuse to concede that a 1-of-N honest RU node assumption is a "trust assumption" of the same class as other typical trust assumptions. It's quite easy to guarantee, can even do fancy proof of custody things to incentivize more full nodes into existence)
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Average-case 15 tx/sec validation load to get guarantees about a 2500 tx/sec thing is amazing, and is 167x scaling.
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat You're still ignoring the really crucial difference between "average case" and "exceptional case".
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Why? You just ask RU full nodes for state as needed, and in the highly exceptional case that zero of them exist you go become one yourself.

@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat If you're already a full client of the base chain (NOT the same thing as being a full client of the rollup!) then you need no trust assumptions.

So zkru is scaling, because a node directly verifying a 15 tx/s thing can get guarantees about a 2500 tx/s thing.
@_prestwich @aliatiia_ @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat Sure. That or you're a light client and are happy trusting majority hashpower.

@aliatiia_ @_prestwich @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat And in a ZK rollup you don't even need that. You know that the base chain is available, so you know that if all else fails you can always fully process the rollup yourself to generate the state, but you almost always don't have to.

@aliatiia_ @_prestwich @ercwl @DZack23 @barrywhitehat As long as you trust the assumption that there exists at least one honest fully verifying node somewhere, you as a light client are fine. This is very different from trusting a specific set of nodes to be honest.

@muellerberndt There's an entirely possible future where in 2021-2022 we shard data first, get 100k TPS rollups, then realize that we don't actually get much more by having more than one shard of base-layer execution capability, and quietly decide to not bother with that part any more.

@CryptoLawRev @himgajria There's definitely a group of "regular but somewhat-wealthy" people to whom the comment you replied to applies. But yeah, focusing on those is better for the short term than for the long term.

There's a common spirit here that I think represents what makes ethereum great, and that we need to double down on.

https://t.co/7PIl5Fh72r
I continue to be bullish on the various permutations of DAICOs too, as well as many of the bonding curve contraptions. Also prediction markets, including micro-scale ones.

DAOs also do a good job of straddling the line of being both exciting and meaningful.

As has quadratic funding. @glenweyl has had a stroke of genius hitting something that's both mathematically optimal *and* fun.

The ideal, of course, is finding things that are both exciting and meaningful. @PoolTogether_ looks like a lottery, but at the same time it's a very creative psychological gadget that could improve people's ability to have savings.

Realistically, many of the most valuable parts of defi are likely to be the most boring: just giving anyone in the world access to a crypto-dollar with an interest rate that matches inflation is already a huge boon to so many people. And we have that; we just need to improve it.

A lot of the flashy stuff is very exciting, but it's short term; the reality is that there's no way that defi will have interest rates more than a percentage point above the best of traditional finance in the long run.

Some people: let's create easy-to-use global-access financial infrastructure and use mechanism design and smart contracts to create new forms of social organization!
Other people: YAY yield farming 135%!!!1!

There's a tension here that we should be talking about more.

@edmundedgar @MrJ3NKS @AriDavidPaul The subtlety is that this is a second-order claim about where the *risks* (ie. variance) get shifted, and not a claim that EIP 1559 introduces new possibilities in terms of *expected values*.

@edmundedgar @MrJ3NKS @AriDavidPaul I would actually argue that it does have the side effect of improving the security/issuance tradeoff, by allowing us to have deflation-in-expectation assuming high usage but at the same time guaranteeing a particular level of security even if usage is much lower than expected.
@DeanEigenmann @LefterisJP Proof of social media is often much less inclusive! I would say it's valuable to have something that's on the middle of that tradeoff between PoSM and a coinvote.
@DeanEigenmann @LefterisJP True, but sending $5 has like a tenth of the effect. So it's much less plutocratic than eg. coin votes.
@JTremback @danrobinson @DeanEigenmann I only support it as one signal among several!
@iquidus Agree in this case you can't! One possibility that doesn't exist here but would exist in many other situations would be to contribute to a competing proposal.
@realLedgerwatch I think that's because the contributions are relatively large and coming from relatively few contributors, so of course the match will be smaller. Working as intended.

The fact that contributing is a costly signal and measures strength of support and not just binary yes/no is important; it helps to ensure the signal is coming from active community members and not just weakly interested bystanders.

We've been looking for ways to gauge community support for protocol changes beyond coinvotes and "proof of social media" for a long time. Coinvotes too plutocratic, social media unclear and attackable. Quadratic funding may be incidentally providing a third alternative.

@mathena It's not a modulo algo, it's a divisibility algo. Taking off 0 preserves zeroness of the modulus.

1002 - 42 = 960, 96 - 56 = 40
1003 - 63 = 940, 94 - 14 = 80
1004 - 14 = 990, 99 - 49 = 50
@cryptochimpanz yes

It's easy to check if a number X divides by 3 or 9 (add the digits), but what about other divisors?

A recursive algo for any X/Y:

1. Find smallest multiple of Y with same last digit as X
2. Subtract, take off the zero
3. Repeat

Example, 1001/7: 1001-21 = 980, 98 - 28 = 70 -> 7

The converse is: if there is no vulnerability, there is no usefulness. If there is NO conceivable event that could disprove your theory, that means your theory doesn't actually help you confidently exclude any possible future state of affairs.

A useful theory will give you some prediction about the future: if X happens, Y will follow. But usefulness of a theory directly leads to vulnerability: if X happens, and Y turns out *not* to follow, then your theory has fallen and you must look for another one.

Unfalsifiability is a concept worth understanding deeply. It *sounds* like a good thing ("yay, my theory is invincible!") but it's not.

Basically, the idea is: if there's no conceivable future that would make you admit your theory is wrong, then your theory is worthless.

@noblessefemina There's definitely many situations where there's even more than three layers, with hierarchies of bigger and smaller (or just parallel) groups that come into conflict with each other.

Conclusion: thinking about conflicts in terms of this three-layer structure (individual vs group vs world) is often the correct frame for better understanding things that thinking about eg. individual vs collective misses.

One example: marketing. How much should a group promote itself? Promotion is good for the group; at world level, zero is bad (you need *some* to get people interested in things) but too much becomes a form of zero-sum conflict between groups.
But even there there's always tensions, and sometimes tensions with no clear answer!

The "polypolitan" ideal is that we want to have many intersecting groups, with none of them becoming far more dominant than the other, because that's the structure that's most likely to preserve both global cooperation *and* individuality.

I'm definitely a proponent of this. https://t.co/0aoBiE78Gt
Hence, even in the internet and cryptocurrency, new groups inevitably re-emerge. The challenge is how to keep these three (not two) layers in balance.

But groups are necessary for human cooperation. We are not "equally spaced atoms"; cooperation inevitably requires each person to work with some people more than others.

And group psychology *is* a powerful tool for cooperation, it would be a shame to throw it away entirely.

The group level is dangerous because self-sacrificially acting for one's group *feels* noble and altruistic, but at world level those actions sometimes end up outright harmful. (Extreme example: brave soldiers fighting for their homelands... which happen to be WW2 Axis powers)
A lot of very successful ideas are successful precisely because they combine individual-oriented and world-oriented thinking: free trade, the early internet, cryptocurrency, etc.

... and it's often the *individualist* mindset that can make closer links with the world at large.

See eg. this picture from Richard A Nisbett's "Geography Of Thought", though this is not just about "East vs West", it applies to more vs less group-oriented thinking everywhere. https://t.co/tVHF4izGJg

We often talk about "individual vs collective", but often the best framing to understand what's going on is "individual vs group vs world". The tricky bit is that what's good for the group and what's good for the world are often in conflict...

@ArthurB @hasufl Costs of block size include:

* Increased (bandwidth, compute, disk space) requirements -> fewer people can run nodes
* Increased uncle rate -> growing centralization risk
* Increased sync times -> worse UX

All of these are roughly linear across a wide range.

@ArthurB @hasufl This implies a model where the cost function of increasing block size is 0 up until some maximum M, and then it shoots up to infinity (or some unacceptably high value) at M+1. That's very far from how pretty much anyone thinks about the costs of block size.
