@benjmnr Oh this is exactly the viewpoint that I fully agree with!

2016-20 is a period of ideological realignment. Many old ideologies and coalitions are dying, and many new ones being born. The hills and valleys on the battlefields are shifting.

The crypto space needs to be watching carefully and adjust to new realities.

I will come out and say this directly: this mentality below is *exactly* what we should be expanding beyond right now. REFORMING MONEY IS NOT SUFFICIENT.

https://t.co/2MakOIFSdB

Though I do think that a broad shift from crypto *just* being finance to crypto also being decentralized governance and organization and community is needed, and is happening.

After all, public goods and community are incredibly important even to the crypto space itself.

Financial censorship (especially the insidious second-order variety where intermediaries get quietly pushed to extrajudicially block use cases that are perfectly legal) continues to be a problem for many marginalized groups and crypto can help.

Within the space of financial apps, I would say the success of stablecoins has shown that what people want is NOT to get away from the USD right this minute, but to move into the crypto *environment* where they have more options of what to do with their money.

Freedom of exit.

Luckily, there's many categories of ethereum applications (and other chains) that go beyond finance. Decentralized censorship-resistant publishing and communication, decentralized communities / governance / DAOs, DAOs for content curation, etc etc. All important work.

Conclusion: finance is relatively less important this decade than it was in the last decade, and the crypto space needs to adjust to this reality. Even *within* finance, some change of emphasis is in order.

And cryptocurrencies ended up being very much correlated to wider economic trends. Doesn't mean they don't protect from other things (eg. political barriers/interference), but it *does* mean that narratives need to adjust. https://t.co/OkStHRNPLR

Yes, the money printer did go brrrrr. But that's a relatively small portion of what is going on, and even there inflation is still going *down* not up.

https://t.co/ZfRiHASsMX

2020 is first and foremost *not* a financial crisis. It's a virus crisis, it's a crisis of epistemology (how we learn what's true and what's false in the face of competing groups misleading us), it's a crisis of overbearing policing in many places, and much more.

And bitcoin itself is primarily a financial tool. Ethereum is explicitly less financial in nature, but even there it remains a fact that a *large* fraction of applications that a blockchain legitimately makes better involve handling coins/tokens/money of some form.

Bitcoin was born out of a crisis that was fundamentally financial in nature. Either the banks misbehaved, or the government over/under/misregulated the financial sector, or they bailed out too many banks, or they printed too many dollars. https://t.co/oPVsNZBd9c

(Including sharding supercharging all of these techniques 100x further down the line)
And the various optimistic systems (incl plasmas) can achieve fast in/out movement with a liquid secondary market for withdrawals-in-progress. We need to start setting up this infrastructure!

So if the wallet detects that the operator is offline, it withdraws your coins and seamlessly switches to being an on-chain wallet. ZK rollups in particular can theoretically allow withdrawals even in the uncooperative-operator case within minutes; imo they should do this.

The operator can't steal; that's the point of L2s instead of sidechains. If it's correctly designed, the operator also can't disappear and permanently freeze the funds. But the L2s should be designed so that if the L2 disappears, you can withdraw funds *as fast as possible*
Though part of that adoption challenge is tightening the guarantees so users will feel comfortable "living" inside an L2 system.
The challenge is that users would need to have wallets where their coins are stored in a rollup (or plasma). This is an adoption challenge, not a technical challenge (CC @metamask_io @ethstatus...).

But even still, token transfers / DEX are a large part of ethereum activity. See tether #1 here https://t.co/zqaQC2s0TJ; also *many* ETH and other ERC20 transfers: https://t.co/emKKIScQ6V

Can we move at least some of these into rollups/plasmas?

First, the systems that are near-ready today are by and large limited to payments and DEX.

There *is* @optimismPBC's Synthetix demo https://t.co/FK4KT5aDmO, which is a *full EVM* inside an opti-rollup, but their work is still earlier-stage than the payments/DEX stuff.
While everyone wasn't looking, the initial deployment of ethereum's layer 2 scaling strategy has *basically* succeeded. What's left is refinement and deployment. A thread:

* Move away from using "ZK" for snarks that are being used for scalability and not zero knowledge

(read the post)
I'd go with the elves, but the question is a very noisy one, because you could argue the elves are wiser because many must already be thousands of years old etc.

One poll I did not have space to make is: what if the 10% supporters are elves who will live 10000 years, the 90% are humans who will on average live 40 years, and the decision will have consequences for 10000 years?

Finally, if one person will be copied *30 minutes in the future*, paradoxically enough from a preference satisfaction standpoint that should be almost the same as them being copied 30 minutes in the past. From an info-gathering standpoint too.

There's gradations here: what if people were copied 5 years ago and lived separately since then? What if people are only partially correlated, because they come from the same backgrounds but do live separate lives? From the info-gathering perspective, individuality is a spectrum.

On the other hand, if the goal of a vote is to aggregate the information in different perspectives, then two perspectives agreeing on something should count more the more different they are. And two people copied 30 minutes ago are almost the same as one person.

If the purpose of a vote is to choose between proposals that satisfy differing end goals of different people, then even if the majority group has very similar opinions, going with the majority still serves the goal of making more people happy.

Fortunately at least a few people got it: the point of these polls was to explore the tradeoff between "voting as preference satisfaction" and "voting as information gathering".

@ArthurB @BobMcElrath @dka218 @austerity_sucks I think the parent means something more like "fundamentally non-neutral".

Circular argument: A therefore B, B therefore A
Spiral argument: A at time T causes B at time T+1, B at time T+1 causes A at time T+2

Circular arguments don't work, but spiral arguments very often do. Learn the difference!

@ArthurB eg. if the decision is "we have $1M, do we spend it on a project that benefits the first group or on a project that benefits the second group", utilitarianism dictates we should favor the first because the very similar people still have independent (future) experiences.

@0xb0b0 @azzabazazz @technocrypto When you measure precision as "digits of precision", you're also implicitly taking a multiplicative width of the range (eg. 97-97.99 has two digits of precision, as does 970-979.9, but 973-973.9 has three digits of precision)

@0xb0b0 @azzabazazz @technocrypto eg. for the EU land area question, someone who says 1-5,000,000 km^2 is in any reasonable intuitive sense giving a much more imprecise answer than someone who says 5,000,000 - 10,000,000 km^2, and yet if you measure linearly the former range would be "narrower".
@Chris_arnade @dandolfa Given the incredibly wide range of outcomes we've seen, counting a 2x difference as "one succeeded and the other failed" seems like an overreaction....

@azzabazazz @technocrypto It's actually really hard to avoid losing many points to values being out of range, even if you try hard! I've played many games where a player just saying "0.000000001 to 1 googleplex" every time would have beaten almost everyone.

@azzabazazz @technocrypto The "lose 20 for out of range, win N for narrowest correct range" rule is designed to approximately encourage players to choose ranges such that the value has a 95% chance of being in range (hence "95% confidence interval game")

@azzabazazz @technocrypto Generally, the game works better if you measure "width" multiplicatively. That is, width = high end / low end, so the range 1-10 million would have width 10, and the range 500k-6m would have width 12.

@azzabazazz @technocrypto Each player comes up with an *interval* that they think the statistic is in (eg. for land area of the EU, someone might guess 1 million - 10 million). Everyone writes their answers down.

@azzabazazz @technocrypto Assume there are N players. In each round, one player (you can go in a circle) comes up with some statistic, that people won't know exactly off the top of their head but which has good internet sources (eg. "land area of EU in km^2", "number of chimpanzees in the world")

@azzabazazz Oh if you want to get good *probabilistic intuitions* (which betting is also great for and which is also important) I recommend @technocrypto's "95% confidence interval" game.

@oikos_cash I said "better" not "above". So given the utility function U, it would be U(A) > U((A+B)/2) and U(B) > U((A+B)/2)

A slight generalization is convexity: (U(A) + U(B))/2 > U((A+B)/2), ie. situations where a coinflip is better than a compromise

https://t.co/cIB816gRRd

And I would say marginalism is *still* underrated by the public. There's lots and lots of cases where having 20% more or less of something is an important social cause, but having 1000% more or none at all would be a disaster, and it continues to be hard to get such points across

Sometimes there are situations where things *are* binary in a certain sense: we don't know if A or B is better, but we know they're both better than the average (A+B)/2. But often the challenge is in identifying whether or not you're in one of those situations in the first place!

One of the more poorly-explained aspects (and benefits) of "thinking like an economist" is seeing things not in terms of black-and-white categories but in terms of quantities and slopes and rates of change.

Don't compare "all A vs all B", compare "1% more A vs 1% more B".

@nicksdjohnson @kevinsekniqi @MatthiasEgli @CollinCusce @el33th4xor I think he's using the BFT definition of synchronous vs asynchronous; if network latency exceeds O(block time), then the main chain grows slowly with mostly uncles and even small attackers can perform 51% attacks and revert arbitrary blocks

@kevinsekniqi @nicksdjohnson @MatthiasEgli @CollinCusce @el33th4xor Blockchains are not like traditional databases, in part because different nodes can't trust each other and in part because you need to worry about risk the system will centralize if load is high.

@kevinsekniqi @nicksdjohnson @MatthiasEgli @CollinCusce @el33th4xor I don't think asynchronous networks give you that much in terms of letting you target more aggressive assumptions; you still need conservative limits to limit DoS and centralization risk, and if you want a dynamic limit there's ways to achieve that in a sync context as well.

@kevinsekniqi @nicksdjohnson @MatthiasEgli @CollinCusce @el33th4xor OK so the bottleneck is broadcasting data. I don't see how the consensus algo affects that; in all cases you just have a proposer generate a block and gossip that block to the network, which seems optimal.

@kevinsekniqi @nicksdjohnson @MatthiasEgli @CollinCusce @el33th4xor The overhead of Nakamoto consensus does not increase with the amount of data it's processing, because coming to consensus on one hash is enough to come to consensus on an unbounded amount of data. So the issue must be something else...

@gregeganSF You can always construct one as a linear combination: given solutions ((x1, y1), (x2, y2)...), do (x-x1)*(x-x2)*(x-x3) + (y-y1)*(y-y2)*(y-y3). You do get extra solutions though.

@gregeganSF Actually on second thought the above assumes P over the integers or some field with characteristic > 625 (sorry, I do cryptography, for me discrete is the default).

For polynomials over the reals, in general the set of zeroes is one-dimensional.....

@gregeganSF Many properties of unidimensional polynomials tend to break down in the multidimensional case. The simplest annoying case is circles. Consider for example the polynomial P(x, y) = x^2 + y^2 - 625. Zeroes include: (0, 25), (7, 24), (15, 20) and rotations/reflections (12 total)

@notyourkeys Oh cryptography is all going to merge into a big jumble of "here's how we efficiently represent everything as polynomials and here are the 73 clever things you can do with a polynomial"

The common theme in both is the rise of cryptographic primitives that operate over boolean or arithmetic circuits as a mathematical representation of computation, and hence cryptographic constructions becoming general purpose.

Prediction:

The megatrend in cryptography of the 2010s was elliptic curves, pairings and general purpose ZKPs/SNARKs.

The megatrend of the 2020s will be (in addition to broad adoption of the above) lattices, LWE, multilinear maps, homomorphic encryption, MPC and obfuscation.

Thread on the philosophy behind MEV auctions

https://t.co/k3WdmSgZA4

CC @optimismPBC

Thus, mechanisms that concentrate and embrace economies of scale (and hence centralization) in one area can drain away economies of scale (and hence lead to more decentralization) in surrounding areas.

This completely separates the economies-of-scale-heavy centralizing task (tx selection) from the decentralized task (validation), and furthermore captures revenue!

And it's bounded risk, because anyone can publish a tx directly to chain and force inclusion in the next batch.

Another even more explicit example of this is miner extractable value (MEV) auctions.

https://t.co/k3WdmSgZA4

Basically, in a rollup, auction off the right to aggregate and choose ordering of transactions to the highest bidder, eg. once per day.

If proposers centralize, this poses much less risk to users than validators centralizing: even if 90% of proposers are bad, the worst they can do is delay transactions an average of 10 slots (~2 min). If they propose bad blocks, validators will ignore them.

The current eth1 -> eth2 roadmap *kinda* has this: eth2 validators have to explicitly sign up to be "eth1 friendly" block proposers.

https://t.co/68DjAWavLz

Proposal is more resource-intensive, validation less resource intensive, validators don't have to be proposers.

Here deliberately engineered bounded centralization comes to the rescue.

What if we split up consensus into two tasks:

1. Choosing what txs go into blocks (complex hence vulnerable to centralization)
2. Verifying others' blocks with txs (routine task hence more decentralizable)

Once there are more complex apps on chain, we see a challenge. Optimal tx inclusion, including capturing "miner extractable value" via frontrunning etc https://t.co/tqyEa24vAQ becomes complicated.

This introduces an edge for sophisticated block proposers, risking centralization.
And it has bounded downside: you don't like one block producer, wait 15 seconds for the next one.

This architecture actually has a lot of benefits, and is by far the most resilient of all architectures we know against bribes / "side payments".

Miners and transaction senders do sometimes make private deals with each other, but the benefit is low so it happens quite little.

Can we combine the two? Well, blockchains combine the two already. Consider the block production mechanism: basically, every 15 seconds we randomly select a dictator, who has total control of what txs they include, and in econ speak is the "full marginal claimant" of the rewards

... but if a single person has large stake+influence, they'll take time to learn and optimize and use economies of scale to make+execute good decisions.

The best arguments against centralization are fragility, risk of abuse of power, low "bus factor" etc etc you know the drill.

The best argument in favor of any centralization is often about concentrated incentive: if a million people each have a tiny stake in an outcome and only tiny ability to influence it, they won't care (or worse, are easily led astray by side incentives)...

Yesterday I talked about the benefits of total decentralization. Today I'll talk about the benefits of deliberately engineered *bounded* centralization.

@_prestwich @gakonst Oh in that case the underlying layer was the not-yet-existent ethereum, not bitcoin.

If you build a dapp on top of fully decentralized / serverless infrastructure, then even if the rest of the community around that infrastructure goes away, your dapp can continue to use it; it may be weaker because of a smaller network effect, but it will still work.

This is why eg. Uniswap, Tornado Cash, and the like so easily excite people to build ecosystems around them while more centralized alternatives fail.

Liveness, not just safety.

People who say "full decentralization is overkill, you only need non-custodial" are missing the point. A fully decentralized (or "serverless") application is valuable because it gives users the confidence that *it will always be there*, so you can safely build on top of it.

@DZack23 Can also send r off-chain eg. via whisper.

Or there could be some fancy technique we have not thought of yet.

@DZack23 The naive solution is to encrypt r with public key P and publish to chain. But this requires receiver to scan through all private sends, so long-run expensive. Could split into T buckets, cut scan time by factor of T but cut anonymity set by factor of T too, so tradeoff.

@DZack23 Stealth addresses are easy: ENS name holder publishes public key P with private key p. Sender generates random r, sends coins to address r*P (that's elliptic curve multiplication). Name holder can spend those coins with r*p. Sender needs to send r to name holder somehow.

Thesis: centralized organization and trust
Antithesis: mountain-man "do everything for yourself" mentality
Synthesis: use blockchains, cryptography, smart contracts and other tech to build new and better, and trust/authority-minimizing, ways for people to cooperate and interact

Thesis: centralized spam protection
Antithesis: unmoderated communications with anonymity/privacy, but lots of spam
Synthesis: spam protection with privacy

Thesis: traditional BFT consensus (cheap, only digital signatures, and has finality, but requires trusted parties)
Antithesis: Nakamoto PoW (open, anyone can participate, but expensive and no finality)
Synthesis: proof of stake (anyone can participate, has finality *and* cheap)

Thesis: trust the integrity of the ledger to third parties
Antithesis: you must personally verify every tx in the entire ledger
Synthesis: intelligent techniques that approach the security of the latter and the efficiency of the former

#sharding #data_availability_checks #snarks

Thesis: trust a centralized third party to hold your assets
Antithesis: pure self-custody
Synthesis: use smart contracts, multisig, social recovery and other techniques to build systems more robust than either.

But for all these challenges, there's a lot of room for human agency in developing new solutions - new internet-enabled ways for people to organize being at the top of the list. I welcome anyone who is willing to rise to the challenge!

But the challenges of a world where everything is based on consumer choice are significant, and IMO the authors' failure to correctly assign great importance to these challenges leads them to fail to predict what 21st century attempts to meet these challenges will look like.

Our sudden realization this year that much more virtualized ways of living are possible should open our minds to the possibility that many of the trends (competitive governance particularly) may come, they'll just lay dormant as ideas for a while and then suddenly spring up.

So all in all, a mixed bag. The book highlights some important trends that will play a part in shaping the world whether we like it or not, but the book's individualist and often proudly anti-egalitarian ethos at times leads it to miss important things.

One mistake the book *does not make* is believing the transition to a cyber world will be quick and easy. It acknowledges the inevitability of backlash, and that regions where everyone's lives are improving (ie. Asia) won't see governments break down quickly. https://t.co/C9CYe5jY9M

Finally, we get to public goods. The book's treatment of public goods is quite perfunctory, focusing on city-level public goods. It completely misses global public goods (especially info: scientific research, code, writing), and the huge benefits of coordinating to provide them. https://t.co/F35AfhEoUi
The book's treatment of cryptocurrency seems to focus on backed tokens (digitized gold deposits etc). But in practice, we saw tokens backed by nothing at all. https://t.co/0IDz1yr1tA
This is part of why even significant levels of taxation are sustainable with not that much effort spent on enforcing them.

And this is a segue into the next topic: the book underestimates trivial inconveniences in general. The bar for annoyance that a government needs to impose to prevent the emergence of a mass market product is just not high. Total banning, near-impossible, nudging, easy.

I've experienced this uphill struggle personally. Ironically cyberspace makes this harder: you can't go "full immersion" because you're always one click away from the lazy comforts of reading tweets originally written in your mother tongue.

If doing something is even somewhat annoying (translations are imperfect, etc), then people will be much less inclined to do it. Hence, most English-speaking people will naturally interact much more with English-speakers than Chinese-speakers (and vice versa), preserving division
As someone who actually learned Chinese I have something to say about this! The reason I am not so optimistic is what rationalists call "trivial inconveniences": https://t.co/vqVZVEtO8o
Another question: what are the remaining things that divide people? One big one in my opinion is language. The book says "eh, universal translators will solve that". https://t.co/fpko4rWi7M
So you get persistence of purpose without relying on persistence of any individual corporate entity.

Real life has an answer that IMO the book failed to predict: cross-organizational collaboration. The zero knowledge proof space that I've spent some time contributing to is a great example: lots of orgs, lots of people, all collaborating without much regard for boundaries.

But here I see a challenge that the book fails to address: where do people get their sense of community and belonging? Religion is dying, nationalism is dying, persistent organizations for work are dying - what replaces that function? No answer.

One major trend that the book predicts is the death of nationalism (including friendly fluffy "civic nationalism") as an ideology. Another is the shift from long-term corporations to short-term orgs that pop in and out of existence. https://t.co/DcCngUy7T1
But these are unimportant details, and ultimately whether it comes to be in 2025 or 2045 is not super important either. What about the important stuff?

But OTOH here's one concrete prediction that still seems way off the mark.

While regional divisions keep existing (eg. https://t.co/EKZwBX0ioO ), Canada's far from literally breaking up and Italy more so. https://t.co/5KQCFpg4uV
Here's one paragraph that looked over-optimistic in 2019 but now seems obvious. https://t.co/iH2eNCS0qr

In 2019, much of this certainly seemed wrong; "markets will rule, politics is pass√©" seemed itself pass√© as politics was coming back with a vengeance. But what if the megapolitical factors that will create this new age are coming after all, just a little bit later than expected?

The book's core prediction is basically "down with voice, up with exit". People would escape bad governments (in this book described largely as those that charge high taxes) and choose among jurisdictions in a competitive market. https://t.co/mMJDXRrt7e

This all sets the stage for Davidson and Rees-Mogg's description of the information age: reduced dependence on physical capital and increased importance of the virtual unwinds all these economies of scale, bringing a transformation as large as that from feudalism to nation states

Democracy (+welfare states) were effective for governments during this time, because people would vote for high taxes that transfer money from business elites to government, funding both welfare and more powerful militaries than governments controlled by elites could muster. https://t.co/B5K3JpsatE

This culminated in the 20th century, when efficient production depended on large scale and fixed physical capital and this made it easy for governments and unions to extract a large surplus. https://t.co/8GcFXGdsWA
Followed by the industrial revolution increasing returns to scale in, well, nearly everything else that mattered. https://t.co/m4p8lq7SY3

In their telling, ~1500 AD saw the end of feudalism and rise of centralized nation states essentially because military tech changes began to favor offense over defense. This reduced power of local lords to resist kings, who could deploy violence with newfound economies of scale. https://t.co/pPOqmmKpB1

Basically, this means things like whether defense is stronger than offense, what the economies of scale are in deploying violence, patterns of communication... structural properties of the world that are shaped largely by technology.

Big questions of how the world is structured are determined primarily not by ideology or wishes, but by "megapolitical factors" - a key term they use as often as Fukuyama uses "isothymia" or Mises uses "praxeology". https://t.co/HIHXvQpJrf
First, let's walk through James Dale Davidson and William Rees-Mogg's model of the world.

Book review tweetstorm: The Sovereign Individual (1999)

https://t.co/WwopQuj8Ro

The book was certainly a inspirational tome for much individualist cypherpunk thought in the 2000s. But what did it concretely predict? And with 2020 hindsight (heh), what was right and what wrong?

@ChazSchmidt We should consider using it as a way to generate proof-of-non-sybil certificates in systems like Whisper or the state provider network in cases where proof of stake-based anti-sybil is impractical.

And many of the changes are actually in the direction of *reducing* complexity.

Look forward to seeing great work continue to happen and for all of this to be put into action!

In addition, there is less reason than ever to fear ever-growing complexity; the "quadratic sharding as end of history" approach ensures there will not need to be a further upgrade as large as the eth1 -> eth2 one; rather, from eth2 onwards things will be much more incremental.
From here, research is continuing, though the bulk of the challenges is now increasingly around development, and development's share of the pie will only continue to grow over time.

Additionally, over the last ~2 years there has been an increasing move toward maintaining compatibility and ensuring a smooth transition for applications, as well as making eth1.x and eth2 fit together as part of a coherent vision.

We know much more about the capabilities and limits of proof of stake, security models of sharding, etc etc. Thanks to the hard work of many, moon math like ZK-SNARKs is looking increasingly down-to-earth.

(PS: the moon is made of Havarti, not Gouda; we checked)

In general, over the last ~2 years there has been a solid shift from "blue sky" research, trying to understand what is possible, to concrete research and development, trying to optimize specific primitives that we know are implementable and implement them.

This is my approximate view of what the next ~5-10 years of eth2 and beyond might look like.

Roadmap below reflects my own views, others (including future versions of me) may have different perspectives! Details may of course change as we discover new info or new tech. https://t.co/wynMVC04Ag

@evan_van_ness @VladZamfir @iseriohn42 Ethereum contract code has a lot of duplication, some total, some partial, and the protocol does a terrible job of pricing in the lower load that duplicate code has to clients in the gas schedule. DELEGATECALL improved this somewhat but it's still very far from enough.
@evan_van_ness @VladZamfir Though on the plus side the uncle mechanism also mitigates discouragement attacks as identified by @iseriohn42 and co. Yay tradeoffs.

@evan_van_ness @VladZamfir The uncle block mechanism has the side effect that a malicious mining pool can degrade the performance and security of the chain at a low cost (sacrifice only ~0.25 ETH instead of 2).

@evan_van_ness @VladZamfir The fact that state objects are not in general assigned to a particular owner is in large part responsible for state rent's dev UX being more complicated. UTXO architectures also do not have this problem to the same extent.

@evan_van_ness @VladZamfir A significant challenge (which UTXO architectures do not have) in solving account abstraction is it becomes possible to have accounts that allow multiple inclusions of the same transaction, so the link between txhash and on-chain event is no longer one-to-one. This complicates UX

@TrustlessState @owocki @LefterisJP Neg-voting N-1 projects is always strictly less efficient, by a factor of sqrt(N), than positive-voting the remaining one project (and vice versa! which is also why "to vote against someone just vote for everyone else" is not a satisfying answer)
@owocki @TrustlessState @LefterisJP Yeah, this is pretty much what would implicitly happen.
@LefterisJP @owocki So in theory, Alice donating $0.001 normally and Bob donating $0.001 with a negative signal would cancel each other out.

@LefterisJP @owocki Mathematically speaking, you process it like any other grant except that for grants marked as negative signals you use the negative square root instead of the positive square root.

@ArthurB At each step, you take a 2^k size tree, copy-paste it to duplicate, and add one node and a left edge and right edge, to get an 2^(k+1) size tree. The latter four steps are constant-time work. Hence constructing a 2^k size tree takes 4k steps.

I disagree with this market-for-consensus ideology because it has nasty equilibria and could easily lead to entrenched interests. This miner group seems to respect the concern (after all, BCH largely gave up market-for-consensus for block size too) and made the fund time-limited: https://t.co/XOgz8FGMWF

This idea was first applied seriously for block size (this is what Bitcoin Unlimited did); is it *that* much of a stretch to also apply it to the 2^160-dimensional parameter of which addresses get what share of the block reward to fund development?

The idea here is that miners should be proposing different consensus rules and trying to enforce them by forking off non-compliant blocks, and this will naturally stabilize toward consensus rules that the majority is okay with.

But at the same time one can also see this as a natural extension of existing BCH ideology, specifically "the market for consensus":

https://t.co/olwHb1CQxa

It's worth noting the irony here: BCH, a chain that was born as a reaction to an ideology that claims that soft forks are the only legitimate way to make changes because they are "voluntary" is.... making a controversial soft fork and insinuating that it's voluntary https://t.co/9XHdh5qUcH

12.5% of the BCH block reward is being redirected from miners to "a Hong Kong corporation". The article bills this as voluntary, but in reality it is of course a compulsory soft fork. https://t.co/DvtLJuwC1G

@sudogene Why?
Hence, QV satisfies the desired rule "how much influence you exert on an issue is proportional to how strongly you care about it".

How much you care about a parameter is proportional to the corresponding variable in your utility function: if you are maximizing ax + by + ..., then `a` determines how much one increment of `x` makes you happier. And the amount by which you end up increasing `x` is... `a`

So they would choose a point on the line ax + by + ... = k for the highest possible k that still intersects with the circle. This line is tangent to the circle. From high school math, we know that the perpendicular vector to ax + by + ... = k is the vector (a, b .... ) https://t.co/n304B0QxNn
Now, how would they vote? Zooming in enough, we can pretend preferences are linear, that is someone is trying to maximize ax + by + ..., where a,b are constants specific to them.

If each person has k voting tokens, we can represent their vote as a right to move the decision from the center of a radius sqrt(k) circle to a point of their choice along the edge. You can see this by pythagorean theorem: (dx)^2 + (dy)^2 = r^2 = k https://t.co/JIJYTIyT1P

@Ray30393725 Given how fundamental public goods are to the infosphere (perhaps the *majority* of infosphere activity is public goods), I think cypherpunks need to learn to appreciate crypto-socialist ideas more!
Special thanks to @VladZamfir for helping me realize the centrality of the issue

There *are* now teams working on solving identity issues with privacy and robustness challenges in mind, and I highly welcome this development. I hope to see the space as well explored in the next 5 years as proof of stake and sharding have been in the last 5.

RadX needs to deeply understand that (i) attempts to measure "identity" or "sociality" will inevitably be attacked by powerful actors, and (ii) privacy is crucial to prevent all human life from becoming a battleground for public favor and official approval, and privacy is *hard*.

Cypherpunks need to realize that in order to thrive they ultimately will need to solve public governance challenges in decentralized communities, and coin voting is just plain terrible. https://t.co/wCjLcUoyxY https://t.co/LTMrsxFeuS
... but a truly synthetic perspective should be able to work well in both worlds.

The main difference in worldviews is arguably survive vs thrive https://t.co/uUHSLFgkJd: cypherpunks assume a much more adversarial worldview, fearing harm from both cops and robbers, RadX assumes more collaborativeness...

The usual cypherpunk view is: identity can be coopted by govts to oppress, coopted by corps to discriminate by nationality, violates privacy and is generally bad juju. When an ability to punish is required, we should instead use security deposits that get burned if you misbehave.

First of all, by identity, I mean attempts to identify properties of the physical human being that controls a particular cryptographic key. A particular use case is the "unique human" problem, constructing a set of cryptographic keys that are each owned by a different person.

It's becoming increasingly clear to me that issues of identity are the main ground of disagreement between many in the crypto community and @RadxChange.

@3blue1brown @bbest12g For FRI, I'd recommend using the degree-2 stepdown rather than the degree-8 version. That is:

P_evens(x^2) = (P(x)+P(-x))/2, P_odds(x^2) = (P(x)-P(-x))/2

deg(P(x)) < N IMPLIES deg((P_evens + r * P_odds)(x)) < N/2

Recurse until N=1.

@zooko I think here the tradeoff is (i) limited resources, (ii) optimizing protocol decisions for one kind of proving vs the other, (iii) if you're choosing between existing protocols rather than making your own

@zooko üòú

https://t.co/KDEGzEmzpx
@zooko Cryptography is more proof-friendly than consensus algos because it does not use behavioral assumptions, but even there, there's lots of soft fuzzy subtlety at play

@zooko What would you rather have? (i) a mathematically flawless argument that a consensus algo is fine if >2/3 are honest, or (ii) a heuristic argument with more English than math symbols about why the algo is fine under a wide variety of assumptions and against all known attacks

@zooko For example, you can formally prove all you want that your consensus algo is guaranteed live and safe if >2/3 honest and <6s network latency. But what if >1/3 stop following the protocol correctly because they're lazy? (eg. SPV mining)

@zooko This viewpoint is easily attacked, because it pattern-matches to recklessness and irresponsibility. But there's a good reason to have this viewpoint: "outside-the-model" attacks are a really big deal, and even the most formal proofs do nothing against them.
@zooko I think you and I both value formality and proofs less than the average academic.

@egfalken Similar mechanics have been used to increase returns to scale (loyalty points and coupons often kinda do this). This is trying to turn that same mechanic toward charitable causes.

That is, the business might sacrifice $100 of profit, but drive $1000 extra worth of donations to a charity they prefer.

A blockchain-based payment and donation system where economic activity is provable can make this much easier to implement at scale

Summary: by offering discounts to people who contributed to some charity, businesses facing conditions of less than perfect competition (meaning: basically everyone) have the ability to "donate" to that charity at high leverage.

Capped Harberger taxes as another hybrid solution for domain names. See thread.

@balajis @azeroz ... *and* they're forced to offer sales through a standard interface instead of brokers or stupid one-on-one negotiations. Oh, and you're also taxing the squatters every year, and your tax can actually capture a substantial portion of the value of the system

@balajis @azeroz Right. The goal is that under harberger tax the optimal price for squatters to set resale prices is proportional to the actual value of the domain, so the squatter ecosystem is incentivized to set prices optimally to avoid domains going too slow *or* too fast...

@balajis @azeroz To clarify, if you pay *less than* $250/year, then someone can grab it from you at a price of (the annual fee you pay) / (the tax rate). You can also get rid of the sharp cliff by making the function asymptotic: buy_price = fee * 250 / tax_rate / (250 - fee) https://t.co/VybsgQHU2y

@balajis @azeroz I recommend starting with a limited price-capped version: if you pay $250/year, no one can take the name away from you. The main goal would be to tax the squatter ecosystem and force it to serve the public good more.
@azeroz @balajis https://t.co/cWF8eAR4Bu

@azeroz @balajis It's a type of partial ownership. Basically, the owner sets a price at which anyone can buy the asset from them, and they must pay a tax proportional to that price.

Goal is to prevent monopoly and holdout problems, and at the same time get revenue that can be used to fund things
@balajis Eh, IMO small-letter names should be Harberger-taxed or something similar. Otherwise the system feels attractive in the short term but first mover privilege corrupts it in the long term.

@robertwiblin @sebkrier @RadxChange You could also buy receipts off other people, but that's technically a collusion problem, not an identity problem, and there are "weak" solutions to that too üòÖ

@robertwiblin @sebkrier @RadxChange ... An example of this is grocery store receipts: you already buy stuff, so your marginal cost of acquiring the first few is zero, but to go beyond that you would have to buy more stuff just to get the receipts.
@robertwiblin @sebkrier @RadxChange Another class of semi-solutions is what I call "weak identity", basically anything where the cost of acquiring N of them is sublinear in N...

@robertwiblin @sebkrier @RadxChange This is both pessimistic and optimistic; pessimistic because lots of things we want to do have a big problem, optimistic because that created a large shared interest in overcoming them.

Both of the above are examples of "positive feedback" processes, where there is some unstable equilibrium at x*, and if you're not exactly at x*, then you move even further away from x* in the same direction. The time you stay within some range is usually -log(abs(x - x*)). https://t.co/dHWVzIx6PH

Another example: you have N mice and 1000 sterile cats, where the mice can reproduce, and the cats eat the mice at a constant rate. You want to maximize the time that the ratio between mouse and cat population stays within some "healthy" range.

@ethanwbrown Here's one possibility (and you can mine positive-feedback processes for more similar answers):

https://t.co/j9baB982y2
@xoryouyou That feels like this (and this is how *most* optimization problems where the optimum is not an extreme point look): https://t.co/3fu2ph3sgn
@onurhsolmaz Something even more tight: a case that contradicts the law of diminishing marginal utility *and* where the optimum is not an extreme point.
@ethanwbrown Looking for a scenario in economics / decision theory, that is where x is some parameter that we can choose, and y represents how happy we are with the outcome

One example: you are putting a small ball on top of a large ball, and want to maximize the time until the small ball slides down (the asymptote is not infinity because you don't care about time linearly, eventually you get bored). The param x would be where you put the small ball

This particular cusp is y = y_max - (x - x_max) ^ (2/3), but yours can be different. The main property I'm looking for is that the closer x gets to x_max, the higher the additional gain from taking x one step closer to x_max.

Challenge of the day: come up with a real-life scenario where the utility function U(x) of setting a parameter to x looks like a cusp.

That is, the optimal value is "somewhere in the middle" and not an extreme, but the slope is higher the closer you get to that optimal point. https://t.co/AZ6c5FEVU0

@balajis One way to do this is to make receipts from purchases dual-use as contributions toward an identity. Consumption is sublinear in income so wealthier people get proportionately fewer identities "for free"
@balajis What you ideally want is for N identities to cost N^2. This is hard to achieve completely, but can try to approximate the idea of making your first few pseudonyms cheaper ...

@balajis The problem with relying purely on this is that someone with N times more resources will have N times more identities, so you still get the problem where the most powerful unfairly win for all the reasons I keep talking about
I also think research around automatically identifying who was at fault for all classes of 51% attacks, including censorship, is important.
And once you have data availability checks, all else can be done with fraud proofs, even in a sharded network.
However, there are lots of good things ZKPs *can* do. Data availability checks https://t.co/o7xPDVs3FP are a great example.

I disagree with the idea that in the long run cryptography will fully supplant cryotoeconomics! Particularly you cannot ZK prove that you did not sign a conflicting message, and so consensus finality will only ever be cryotoeconomic.

The second is to do sharding, so the amount of data you have to process scales linearly with how many coins you are staking, at least up until the maximum where if you have a large fraction of staked coins you are processing everything. This cuts down economies of scale.

There are two other anti-centralization techniques that the post misses. The first is to have forgiving protocol rules that do not require nodes to have especially high performance. Make sure even 70% uptime validation is net-profitable, don't have ultra-fast block times, etc.

@ChrisLundkvist @BobMcElrath It's almost like there is a "proof of stake FAQ" containing all these arguments that you can google for...

@ChrisLundkvist @BobMcElrath No, capital costs of PoS are not the same as costs of PoW, because PoW requires permanent investment whereas PoS only requires temporary depositing, and even PoW ASICs only have a ~2 year lifespan and high opex whereas PoS is much closer to pure capex.

@ChrisLundkvist @BobMcElrath No, the security of PoS is not a circular argument, it's an argument by induction (the thing is fine at time T therefore it will be fine at time T+1), and induction arguments are perfectly sound.

@ChrisLundkvist @BobMcElrath No, a 51% attack on PoS is not irrecoverable because you can always UASF out of it. A 51% attack on PoW, OTOH, seems recoverable but actually a spawn camp attack is really not, and "get more hashpower from the outside" is a hard coordination problem.

@ChrisLundkvist @BobMcElrath Yeah, pretty much this. Yes, we know about weak subjectivity. Yes, we are by and large fine with it, though we keep coming up with more and more mitigations. No, PoW is not more egalitarian than PoS and has not been since 2014.

@jasonhickel To accurately calculate this, we'd need the source data that gives actual income distributions in each year, but heuristically, what goes on at the $1.90, $3.80 and $7.60 levels is about equally important.

@jasonhickel As far as the latter goes (which poverty line to use), the real answer is of course that using any line is simplistic. The economist's standard estimate for welfare as a function of consumption is U = log(money), so we should be measuring average log(money) at any time.

@LefKok @zetavar1 @rogwattenhofer Ah okay, I misread then. Got it.
@matt_garnett @LefKok @zetavar1 @rogwattenhofer Proving data availability is much cheaper than personally downloading the data.
@LefKok @zetavar1 @rogwattenhofer If a shard is malicious and no honest party holds the data, then no client (on any shard) would accept a block that recognizes a block of that shard.
@LefKok @zetavar1 @rogwattenhofer Also, the above bound applies to the *space* scaling factor. Stateless clients remove the need for validators to store more than O(1) space.

@LefKok @zetavar1 @rogwattenhofer My response to this is twofold:

1. Fraud proofs and data availability proofs
2. If (1) is not available, don't assume a hyper-adaptive adversary.

Of course, eth2 is designed with (1) in mind long-term.

@LefKok @zetavar1 @rogwattenhofer This section is actually really pessimistic! It's basically saying that a sharded blockchain with N nodes can only "securely" provide capacity log(N) times higher than a non-sharded blockchain. @LefKok @zetavar1 @rogwattenhofer I'll point out that fraud proofs and data availability proofs nullify the reasoning here. More academics should take fraud + data availability proofs seriously! https://t.co/Myn8AVfU3G

@LefKok @zetavar1 @rogwattenhofer This is basically saying that if you keep reassigning validators to shards, eventually each validator will be required to download the full state of most shards, correct?

Protip: to make an arithmetic circuit constraint implement a non-zeroness check, add another input w, and check that (c(x1..xn) * w) - 1 = 0

Programming languages: 0 is false, everything else is true
Arithmetic circuit constraints: 0 is true, everything else is false

@bitfalls @AFDudley0 @drakefjustin @0xstark @icebearhww @dannyryan @benjaminion_xyz In the current proposals it's easy to design a contract that pings a central registry every time it switches shards. But you could also make a layer-2 protocol for this (client asks network which shard a contract is on, network replies with a proof)

@AFDudley0 @drakefjustin @0xstark @icebearhww @dannyryan @benjaminion_xyz The protocol doesn't assign contracts to shards, you assign contracts to shards, and once created contract code gives permission for the contract to be yanked to a different shard.

@AFDudley0 @drakefjustin @0xstark @icebearhww @dannyryan @benjaminion_xyz > Fees aren't compelling enough in the pathological case to balance load.

Why not? Every shard has a separate gas limit, so in a sufficiently pathological case fees can rise sufficiently high pretty quickly.

@AFDudley0 @drakefjustin @0xstark @icebearhww @dannyryan @benjaminion_xyz 2. It's economically self-balancing. If there's high activity on one shard, that shard's gas prices go up, so all other users are incentivized to maximally move their activity to other shards.

@AFDudley0 @drakefjustin @0xstark @icebearhww @dannyryan @benjaminion_xyz 1. In the current proposal (see  https://t.co/hycMQziKsS)  contracts have a fixed max size, so you're really talking about a large  *system of contracts*. This distinction is important because contracts  in a system are separately yankable between shards.

@RyanSAdams I would say it's the *non-scalability goodies* that depend on layer 2 stuff. Including:

* Fast cross-shard comms
* Privacy
* User experience (eg. paying for gas on others' behalf)

@MatGroennebaek @glenweyl @oliverbeige @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig Actually, I take that back. You can have *profits* under zero monopoly power if your marginal costs are increasing. But then your *marginal* profit per item is zero, your *average* profit per item would be positive.

@MatGroennebaek @glenweyl @oliverbeige @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig I'm not trying to claim that "a guy with a bag of rice is literally the same as Standard Oil". Monopoly power is a spectrum, its influence is rarely exactly zero, though its influence varies widely between different kinds of circumstances.

@MatGroennebaek @glenweyl @oliverbeige @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig Profit margins are only possible under nonzero monopoly power.

(Note that you don't need profit margins to *make money*, it could be that your revenues minus your expenses are just the price of your own labor. But these two types of gains *are* economically different)

@MatGroennebaek @glenweyl @oliverbeige @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig For example, the equilibrium price of rice would be different if (i) you had a 40kg rice bag and were the only seller within 1km vs (ii) you had a 10kg rice bag, three other people had 10kg rice bags, and those four were the sellers within 1km.

@MatGroennebaek @glenweyl @oliverbeige @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig Monopoly power happens when your optimal behavior is to charge prices higher than your reserve price, ie. push prices up even at the cost of turning away some otherwise profitable deals. Not the same as scarcity.

@MatGroennebaek @glenweyl @oliverbeige @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig Monopoly power depends also on lack of substitutes. If your rice is the only rice within 1km of someone, then yeah, you have some monopoly power. If you're standing outside Whole Foods and there's a bunch more rice inside the store that anyone can buy, then not so much.
@oliverbeige @glenweyl @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig This problem has been mitigated in real life by requiring apartment buyouts to only have 80% consent in many cases.

@oliverbeige @glenweyl @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig The point is that the owner has some "thing" that they can choose to make available to the market at some cost X to themselves if it gets claimed. That's economically isomorphic to production.

@oliverbeige @glenweyl @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig I don't think any of us advocate doing anything to consumer property at the very least until we see what happens in many kinds of industrial deployments.

@MatGroennebaek @glenweyl @oliverbeige @Nicolas_Colin @zhitzig @MattBruenig At the very least that requires you to offer a price that gives a >98% success rate per buyer, which is a *lot* of deadweight loss.
